style.properties.font-variant-position.d: The font-variant-position CSS property controls the use of alternate, smaller glyphs that are positioned as superscript or subscript.
style.properties.font-variant-position.v: Deactivates alternate superscript and subscript glyphs.
Activates subscript alternate glyphs. If, in a given run, one such glyph is not available for a character, all the characters in the run are rendered using synthesized glyphs.
Activates superscript alternate glyphs. If, in a given run, one such glyph is not available for a character, all the characters in the run are rendered using synthesized glyphs.
style.properties.font-variant.descriptio: The font-variant CSS shorthand property allows you to set all the font variants for a font.
style.properties.font-variant.values.all: Specifies the keywords and functions related to the font-variant-caps longhand property. The small-caps value is the only non-normal font variant valid within the font shorthand property.
Specifies the keywords and functions related to the font-variant-caps longhand property. The small-caps value is the only non-normal font variant valid within the font shorthand property.
style.properties.font-variant.values.ann: Specifies the keywords and functions related to the font-variant-ligatures longhand property.
style.properties.font-variant.values.cha: Specifies the keywords and functions related to the font-variant-ligatures longhand property.
style.properties.font-variant.values.emo: Specifies the keywords and functions related to the font-variant-emoji longhand property.
style.properties.font-variant.values.his: Specifies the keywords and functions related to the font-variant-ligatures longhand property.
style.properties.font-variant.values.non: Sets the value of the font-variant-ligatures as none and the values of the other longhand properties as normal, their initial value.
style.properties.font-variant.values.nor: Specifies a normal font face. Each longhand property has an initial value of normal.
style.properties.font-variant.values.ord: Specifies the keywords related to the font-variant-numeric longhand property. The possible values are lining-nums, oldstyle-nums, proportional-nums, tabular-nums, diagonal-fractions, stacked-fractions, ordinal, and slashed-zero.
style.properties.font-variant.values.orn: Specifies the keywords and functions related to the font-variant-ligatures longhand property.
style.properties.font-variant.values.pet: Specifies the keywords and functions related to the font-variant-caps longhand property. The small-caps value is the only non-normal font variant valid within the font shorthand property.
style.properties.font-variant.values.rub: Specifies the keywords related to the font-variant-east-asian longhand property. The possible values are jis78, jis83, jis90, jis04, simplified, traditional, full-width, proportional-width, and ruby.
style.properties.font-variant.values.sla: Specifies the keywords related to the font-variant-numeric longhand property. The possible values are lining-nums, oldstyle-nums, proportional-nums, tabular-nums, diagonal-fractions, stacked-fractions, ordinal, and slashed-zero.
style.properties.font-variant.values.sma: Specifies the keywords and functions related to the font-variant-caps longhand property. The small-caps value is the only non-normal font variant valid within the font shorthand property.
style.properties.font-variant.values.sty: Specifies the keywords and functions related to the font-variant-ligatures longhand property.
Specifies the keywords and functions related to the font-variant-ligatures longhand property.
style.properties.font-variant.values.sub: Specifies the keywords and functions related to the font-variant-position longhand property.
style.properties.font-variant.values.sup: Specifies the keywords and functions related to the font-variant-position longhand property.
style.properties.font-variant.values.swa: Specifies the keywords and functions related to the font-variant-ligatures longhand property.
style.properties.font-variant.values.tex: Specifies the keywords and functions related to the font-variant-emoji longhand property.
style.properties.font-variant.values.tit: Specifies the keywords and functions related to the font-variant-caps longhand property. The small-caps value is the only non-normal font variant valid within the font shorthand property.
style.properties.font-variant.values.uni: Specifies the keywords and functions related to the font-variant-caps longhand property. The small-caps value is the only non-normal font variant valid within the font shorthand property.
Specifies the keywords and functions related to the font-variant-emoji longhand property.
style.properties.font-variation-settings: The font-variation-settings CSS property provides low-level control over variable font characteristics by letting you specify the four letter axis names of the characteristics you want to vary along with their values.
Text is laid out using default settings.
style.properties.font-weight.description: The font-weight CSS property sets the weight (or boldness) of the font. The weights available depend on the font-family that is currently set.
style.properties.font-weight.values.bold: One relative font weight heavier than the parent element. Note that only four font weights are considered for relative weight calculation; see the Meaning of relative weights section below.
style.properties.font-weight.values.ligh: One relative font weight lighter than the parent element. Note that only four font weights are considered for relative weight calculation; see the Meaning of relative weights section below.
style.properties.font.description: The font CSS shorthand property sets all the different properties of an element's font. Alternatively, it sets an element's font to a system font.
style.properties.font.values.bolder.desc: Specifies the weight of the face bolder than the inherited value.
style.properties.font.values.caption.des: The system font used for captioned controls (e.g., buttons, drop-downs, etc.).
style.properties.font.values.icon.descri: The system font used to label icons.
style.properties.font.values.italic.desc: Selects a font that is labeled 'italic', or, if that is not available, one labeled 'oblique'.
style.properties.font.values.lighter.des: Specifies the weight of the face lighter than the inherited value.
style.properties.font.values.menu.descri: The system font used in menus (e.g., dropdown menus and menu lists).
style.properties.font.values.message-box: The system font used in dialog boxes.
style.properties.font.values.normal.desc: Specifies a face that is not labeled as a small-caps font.
style.properties.font.values.oblique.des: Selects a font that is labeled 'oblique'.
Specifies a font that is labeled as a small-caps font. If a genuine small-caps font is not available, user agents should simulate a small-caps font.
style.properties.font.values.small-capti: The system font used for labeling small controls.
The system font used in window status bars.
style.properties.forced-color-adjust.des: The forced-color-adjust CSS property allows authors to opt certain elements out of forced colors mode. This then restores the control of those values to CSS.
style.properties.forced-color-adjust.val: The element's colors are adjusted by the user agent in forced colors mode. This is the default.
The element's colors are not automatically adjusted by the user agent in forced colors mode.
style.properties.gap.description: The gap CSS shorthand property sets the gaps (gutters) between rows and columns.
style.properties.glyph-orientation-horiz: Controls glyph orientation when the inline-progression-direction is horizontal.
style.properties.glyph-orientation-verti: Controls glyph orientation when the inline-progression-direction is vertical.
Sets the orientation based on the fullwidth or non-fullwidth characters and the most common orientation.
style.properties.grid-area.description: The grid-area CSS shorthand property specifies a grid item's size and location within a grid by contributing a line, a span, or nothing (automatic) to its grid placement, thereby specifying the edges of its grid area.
style.properties.grid-area.values.auto.d: Is a keyword indicating that the property contributes nothing to the grid item's placement, indicating auto-placement or a default span of 1.
style.properties.grid-area.values.span &:
Contributes a grid span to the grid item's placement such that the corresponding edge of the grid item's grid area is n lines from the opposite edge.
    If a name is given as a <custom-ident>, only lines with that name are counted. If not enough lines with that name exist, all implicit grid lines on the side of the explicit grid corresponding to the search direction are assumed to have that name for the purpose of counting this span.
    If the <integer> is omitted, it defaults to 1. Negative integers or 0 are invalid.
style.properties.grid-area.values.span.d: Contributes a grid span to the grid item's placement such that the corresponding edge of the grid item's grid area is N lines from its opposite edge.
style.properties.grid-auto-columns.descr: The grid-auto-columns CSS property specifies the size of an implicitly-created grid column track or pattern of tracks.
style.properties.grid-auto-columns.value:
As a maximum represents the largest max-content size of the items in that track.
    As a minimum represents the largest minimum size of items in that track (specified by the min-width/min-height of the items). This is often, though not always, the min-content size.
    If used outside of minmax() notation, auto represents the range between the minimum and maximum described above. This behaves similarly to minmax(min-content,max-content) in most cases.
    
      Note: auto track sizes (and only auto track sizes) can be stretched by the align-content and justify-content properties. Therefore by default, an auto sized track will take up any remaining space in the grid container.

Represents the formula min(max-content, max(auto, argument)), which is calculated similar to auto (i.e. minmax(auto, max-content)), except that the track size is clamped at argument if it is greater than the auto minimum.
相当于公式 min(max-content, max(auto, argument))，类似于auto 的计算 (即 minmax(auto, max-content))，除了网格轨道大小值是确定下来的，否则该值都大于 auto 的最小值。
Is a keyword representing the largest maximal content contribution of the grid items occupying the grid track.
Is a keyword representing the largest minimal content contribution of the grid items occupying the grid track.
Defines a size range greater than or equal to min and less than or equal to max.

Is a functional notation that defines a size range greater than or equal to min and less than or equal to max. If max is smaller than min, then max is ignored and the function is treated as min. As a maximum, a <flex> value sets the track's flex factor. As a minimum, it is treated as zero (or minimal content, if the grid container is sized under a minimal content constraint).
style.properties.grid-auto-flow.descript: The grid-auto-flow CSS property controls how the auto-placement algorithm works, specifying exactly how auto-placed items get flowed into the grid.
style.properties.grid-auto-flow.values.c: Items are placed by filling each column in turn, adding new columns as necessary.
style.properties.grid-auto-flow.values.d:
"dense" packing algorithm attempts to fill in holes earlier in the grid, if smaller items come up later. This may cause items to appear out-of-order, when doing so would fill in holes left by larger items.
    If it is omitted, a "sparse" algorithm is used, where the placement algorithm only ever moves "forward" in the grid when placing items, never backtracking to fill holes. This ensures that all of the auto-placed items appear "in order", even if this leaves holes that could have been filled by later items.
style.properties.grid-auto-flow.values.r: Items are placed by filling each row in turn, adding new rows as necessary. If neither row nor column is provided, row is assumed.
style.properties.grid-auto-rows.descript: The grid-auto-rows CSS property specifies the size of an implicitly-created grid row track or pattern of tracks.
style.properties.grid-auto-rows.values.a:
As a maximum represents the largest max-content size of the items in that track.
    As a minimum represents the largest minimum size of items in that track (specified by the min-width/min-height of the items). This is often, though not always, the min-content size.
    If used outside of minmax() notation, auto represents the range between the minimum and maximum described above. This behaves similarly to minmax(min-content,max-content) in most cases.
    
      Note: auto track sizes (and only auto track sizes) can be stretched by the align-content and justify-content properties. Therefore by default, an auto sized track will take up any remaining space in the grid container.
style.properties.grid-auto-rows.values.f: Represents the formula min(max-content, max(auto, argument)), which is calculated similar to auto (i.e. minmax(auto, max-content)), except that the track size is clamped at argument if it is greater than the auto minimum.
style.properties.grid-auto-rows.values.m: Is a keyword representing the largest maximal content contribution of the grid items occupying the grid track.
Is a keyword representing the largest minimal content contribution of the grid items occupying the grid track.
Defines a size range greater than or equal to min and less than or equal to max.

Is a functional notation that defines a size range greater than or equal to min and less than or equal to max. If max is smaller than min, then max is ignored and the function is treated as min. As a maximum, a <flex> value sets the track's flex factor. As a minimum, it is treated as zero (or minimal content, if the grid container is sized under a minimal content constraint).
style.properties.grid-column-end.descrip: The grid-column-end CSS property specifies a grid item's end position within the grid column by contributing a line, a span, or nothing (automatic) to its grid placement, thereby specifying the block-end edge of its grid area.
Is a keyword indicating that the property contributes nothing to the grid item's placement, indicating auto-placement, an automatic span, or a default span of 1.

Contributes a grid span to the grid item's placement such that the column end edge of the grid item's grid area is n lines from the start edge.
    If a name is given as a <custom-ident>, only lines with that name are counted. If not enough lines with that name exist, all implicit grid lines on the side of the explicit grid corresponding to the search direction are assumed to have that name for the purpose of counting this span.
    If the <integer> is omitted, it defaults to 1. Negative integers or 0 are invalid.
    The <custom-ident> cannot take the span value.
Contributes a grid span to the grid item's placement such that the corresponding edge of the grid item's grid area is N lines from its opposite edge.
style.properties.grid-column-gap.descrip: Specifies the gutters between grid columns. Replaced by 'column-gap' property.
style.properties.grid-column-start.descr: The grid-column-start CSS property specifies a grid item's start position within the grid column by contributing a line, a span, or nothing (automatic) to its grid placement. This start position defines the block-start edge of the grid area.
style.properties.grid-column-start.value: A keyword indicating that the property contributes nothing to the grid item's placement, indicating auto-placement, an automatic span, or a default span of 1.

Contributes a grid span to the grid item's placement, such that the column start edge of the grid item's grid area is n lines from the end edge.
    If a name is given as a <custom-ident>, only lines with that name are counted. If not enough lines with that name exist, all implicit grid lines on the side of the explicit grid corresponding to the search direction are assumed to have that name for the purpose of counting this span.
    If the <integer> is omitted, it defaults to 1. Negative integers and 0 are invalid.
    The <custom-ident> cannot take the span value.
Contributes a grid span to the grid item's placement such that the corresponding edge of the grid item's grid area is N lines from its opposite edge.
style.properties.grid-column.description: The grid-column CSS shorthand property specifies a grid item's size and location within a grid column by contributing a line, a span, or nothing (automatic) to its grid placement, thereby specifying the inline-start and inline-end edge of its grid area.
style.properties.grid-column.values.auto: The property contributes nothing to the grid item's placement, indicating auto-placement, an automatic span, or a default span of one.
style.properties.grid-column.values.span: Contributes a grid span to the grid item's placement such that the corresponding edge of the grid item's grid area is N lines from its opposite edge.
style.properties.grid-gap.description: Shorthand that specifies the gutters between grid columns and grid rows in one declaration. Replaced by 'gap' property.
style.properties.grid-row-end.descriptio: The grid-row-end CSS property specifies a grid item's end position within the grid row by contributing a line, a span, or nothing (automatic) to its grid placement, thereby specifying the inline-end edge of its grid area.
style.properties.grid-row-end.values.aut: Is a keyword indicating that the property contributes nothing to the grid item's placement, indicating auto-placement, an automatic span, or a default span of 1.
style.properties.grid-row-end.values.spa:
Contributes a grid span to the grid item's placement such that the row end edge of the grid item's grid area is n lines from the start edge.
    If a name is given as a <custom-ident>, only lines with that name are counted. If not enough lines with that name exist, all implicit grid lines on the side of the explicit grid corresponding to the search direction are assumed to have that name for the purpose of counting this span.
    If the <integer> is omitted, it defaults to 1. Negative integers or 0 are invalid.
Contributes a grid span to the grid item's placement such that the corresponding edge of the grid item's grid area is N lines from its opposite edge.
style.properties.grid-row-gap.descriptio: Specifies the gutters between grid rows. Replaced by 'row-gap' property.
style.properties.grid-row-start.descript: The grid-row-start CSS property specifies a grid item's start position within the grid row by contributing a line, a span, or nothing (automatic) to its grid placement, thereby specifying the inline-start edge of its grid area.
style.properties.grid-row-start.values.a: Is a keyword indicating that the property contributes nothing to the grid item's placement, indicating auto-placement, an automatic span, or a default span of 1.
style.properties.grid-row-start.values.s:
Contributes a grid span to the grid item's placement; such that the row start edge of the grid item's grid area is n lines from the end edge.
    If a name is given as a <custom-ident>, only lines with that name are counted. If not enough lines with that name exist, all implicit grid lines on the side of the explicit grid, corresponding to the search direction, are assumed to have that name for the purpose of counting this span.
    If the <integer> is omitted, it defaults to 1. Negative integers or 0 are invalid.
    The <custom-ident> cannot take the span value.
Contributes a grid span to the grid item's placement such that the corresponding edge of the grid item's grid area is N lines from its opposite edge.
style.properties.grid-row.description: The grid-row CSS shorthand property specifies a grid item's size and location within a grid row by contributing a line, a span, or nothing (automatic) to its grid placement, thereby specifying the inline-start and inline-end edge of its grid area.
style.properties.grid-row.values.auto.de: Is a keyword indicating that the property contributes nothing to the grid item's placement, indicating auto-placement, an automatic span, or a default span of 1.
style.properties.grid-row.values.span &&:
Contributes a grid span to the grid item's placement such that the corresponding edge of the grid item's grid area is n lines from the opposite edge.
    If a name is given as a <custom-ident>, only lines with that name are counted. If not enough lines with that name exist, all implicit grid lines on the side of the explicit grid corresponding to the search direction are assumed to have that name for the purpose of counting this span.
    If the <integer> is omitted, it defaults to 1. Negative integers or 0 are invalid.
style.properties.grid-row.values.span.de: Contributes a grid span to the grid item's placement such that the corresponding edge of the grid item's grid area is N lines from its opposite edge.
style.properties.grid-template-areas.des: The grid-template-areas CSS property specifies named grid areas, establishing the cells in the grid and assigning them names.
style.properties.grid-template-areas.val: The grid container doesn't define any named grid areas.
style.properties.grid-template-columns.d: The grid-template-columns CSS property defines the line names and track sizing functions of the grid columns.
style.properties.grid-template-columns.v: A <custom-ident> specifying a name for the line in that location. The ident may be any valid string other than the reserved words span and auto. Lines may have multiple names separated by a space inside the square brackets, for example [line-name-a line-name-b].

As a maximum represents the largest max-content size of the items in that track.
    As a minimum represents the largest minimum size of items in that track (specified by the min-width/min-height of the items). This is often, though not always, the min-content size.
    If used outside of minmax() notation, auto represents the range between the minimum and maximum described above. This behaves similarly to minmax(min-content,max-content) in most cases.
    
      Note: auto track sizes (and only auto track sizes) can be stretched by the align-content and justify-content properties. Therefore by default, an auto sized track will take up any remaining space in the grid container.

Represents the formula max(minimum, min(limit, max-content)), where minimum represents an auto minimum (which is often, but not always, equal to a min-content minimum), and limit is the track sizing function passed as an argument to fit-content(). This is essentially calculated as the smaller of minmax(auto, max-content) and minmax(auto, limit).
The masonry value indicates that this axis should be laid out according to the masonry algorithm.

Is a keyword representing the largest maximal content contribution of the grid items occupying the grid track. For example, if the first element of the grid track contains the sentence "Repetitio est mater studiorum" and the second element contains the sentence "Dum spiro, spero", maximal content contribution will be defined by the size of the largest sentence among all of the grid elements - "Repetitio est mater studiorum".

Is a keyword representing the largest minimal content contribution of the grid items occupying the grid track. For example, if the first element of the grid track contains the sentence "Repetitio est mater studiorum" and the second element contains the sentence "Dum spiro, spero", minimal content contribution will be defined by the size of the largest word among all of the sentences in the grid elements - "studiorum".
Defines a size range greater than or equal to min and less than or equal to max.

Is a functional notation that defines a size range greater than or equal to min and less than or equal to max. If max is smaller than min, then max is ignored and the function is treated as min. As a maximum, a <flex> value sets the track's flex factor. It is invalid as a minimum.
Indicates that there is no explicit grid. Any columns will be implicitly generated and their size will be determined by the grid-auto-columns property.
Represents a repeated fragment of the track list, allowing a large number of columns that exhibit a recurring pattern to be written in a more compact form.
Represents a repeated fragment of the track list, allowing a large number of columns or rows that exhibit a recurring pattern to be written in a more compact form.

The subgrid value indicates that the grid will adopt the spanned portion of its parent grid in that axis. Rather than being specified explicitly, the sizes of the grid rows/columns will be taken from the parent grid's definition.
style.properties.grid-template-rows.desc: The grid-template-rows CSS property defines the line names and track sizing functions of the grid rows.
style.properties.grid-template-rows.valu: A <custom-ident> specifying a name for the line in that location. The ident may be any valid string other than the reserved words span and auto. Lines may have multiple names separated by a space inside the square brackets, for example [line-name-a line-name-b].

As a maximum represents the largest max-content size of the items in that track.
    As a minimum represents the largest minimum size of items in that track (specified by the min-width/min-height of the items). This is often, though not always, the min-content size.
    If used outside of minmax() notation, auto represents the range between the minimum and maximum described above. This behaves similarly to minmax(min-content,max-content) in most cases.
    
      Note: auto track sizes (and only auto track sizes) can be stretched by the align-content and justify-content properties. Therefore by default, an auto sized track will take up any remaining space in the grid container.

Represents the formula min(max-content, max(auto, argument)), which is calculated similar to auto (i.e. minmax(auto, max-content)), except that the track size is clamped at argument if it is greater than the auto minimum.
The masonry value indicates that this axis should be laid out according to the masonry algorithm.
Is a keyword representing the largest maximal content contribution of the grid items occupying the grid track.
Is a keyword representing the largest minimal content contribution of the grid items occupying the grid track.
Defines a size range greater than or equal to min and less than or equal to max.

Is a functional notation that defines a size range, greater than or equal to min, and less than or equal to max. If max is smaller than min, then max is ignored and the function is treated as min. As a maximum, a <flex> value sets the track's flex factor. It is invalid as a minimum.
Is a keyword meaning that there is no explicit grid. Any rows will be implicitly generated and their size will be determined by the grid-auto-rows property.
Represents a repeated fragment of the track list, allowing a large number of rows that exhibit a recurring pattern to be written in a more compact form.
Represents a repeated fragment of the track list, allowing a large number of columns or rows that exhibit a recurring pattern to be written in a more compact form.

The subgrid value indicates that the grid will adopt the spanned portion of its parent grid in that axis. Rather than being specified explicitly, the sizes of the grid rows/columns will be taken from the parent grid's definition.
style.properties.grid-template.descripti: The grid-template CSS property is a shorthand property for defining grid columns, grid rows, and grid areas.
style.properties.grid-template.values.[:
Sets grid-template-areas to the strings listed, grid-template-rows to the track sizes following each string (filling in auto for any missing sizes), and splicing in the named lines defined before/after each size, and grid-template-columns to the track listing specified after the slash (or none, if not specified).
    
      Note: The repeat() function isn't allowed in these track listings, as the tracks are intended to visually line up one-to-one with the rows/columns in the "ASCII art".
style.properties.grid-template.values.au: As a maximum, identical to 'max-content'. As a minimum, represents the largest minimum size (as specified by min-width/min-height) of the grid items occupying the grid track.
style.properties.grid-template.values.ma: Represents the largest max-content contribution of the grid items occupying the grid track.
style.properties.grid-template.values.mi: Represents the largest min-content contribution of the grid items occupying the grid track.
Defines a size range greater than or equal to min and less than or equal to max.
style.properties.grid-template.values.no: Is a keyword that sets all three longhand properties to none, meaning there is no explicit grid. There are no named grid areas. Rows and columns will be implicitly generated; their size will be determined by the grid-auto-rows and grid-auto-columns properties.
style.properties.grid-template.values.re: Represents a repeated fragment of the track list, allowing a large number of columns or rows that exhibit a recurring pattern to be written in a more compact form.
style.properties.grid-template.values.su: Sets 'grid-template-rows' and 'grid-template-columns' to 'subgrid', and 'grid-template-areas' to its initial value.
style.properties.grid.description: The grid CSS property is a shorthand property that sets all of the explicit and implicit grid properties in a single declaration.
style.properties.grid.values.column.desc: 所有其余 grid 次级属性被重置为初始值。
style.properties.grid.values.grid-auto-c: 所有其余 grid 次级属性被重置为初始值。
style.properties.grid.values.grid-auto-f: 所有其余 grid 次级属性被重置为初始值。
style.properties.grid.values.grid-auto-r: 所有其余 grid 次级属性被重置为初始值。
style.properties.grid.values.grid-templa: 所有其余 grid 次级属性被重置为初始值。
所有其余 grid 次级属性被重置为初始值。
style.properties.grid.values.none.descri: 所有其余 grid 次级属性被重置为初始值。
style.properties.hanging-punctuation.des: The hanging-punctuation CSS property specifies whether a punctuation mark should hang at the start or end of a line of text. Hanging punctuation may be placed outside the line box.
style.properties.hanging-punctuation.val: A stop or comma at the end of a line hangs if it does not otherwise fit prior to justification.

An opening bracket or quote at the start of the first formatted line of an element hangs. This applies to:
    
      all characters in the Unicode categories Ps, Pf, Pi
      the quote marks U+0027 APOSTROPHE (') and U+0022 QUOTATION MARK (").
A stop or comma at the end of a line hangs.

A closing bracket or quote at the end of the last formatted line of an element hangs. This applies to:
    
      all characters in the Unicode categories Pe, Pf, Pi
      the quote marks U+0027 APOSTROPHE (') and U+0022 QUOTATION MARK (").
style.properties.height.description: The height CSS property specifies the height of an element. By default, the property defines the height of the content area. If box-sizing is set to border-box, however, it instead determines the height of the border area.
style.properties.height.values.auto.desc: The browser will calculate and select a height for the specified element.
style.properties.height.values.available: 包含块高度减去当前元素的边距，边框和填充。
style.properties.height.values.border-bo: 如果设置该值，则 <length> 或者 <percentage> 会设置为该元素的 border box。
style.properties.height.values.clamp().d: Enables selecting a middle value within a range of values between a defined minimum and maximum
style.properties.height.values.content-b: 如果设置该值，则 <length> 或者 <percentage> 会设置为该元素的 content box。
style.properties.height.values.fill.desc: 根据文字方向，使用 fill-available 作为行大小或者块大小。
style.properties.height.values.fit-conte: Uses the fit-content formula with the available space replaced by the specified argument, i.e. min(max-content, max(min-content, <length-percentage>))
Box will use the available space, but never more than max-content
style.properties.hyphenate-character.des: The hyphenate-character CSS property sets the character (or string) used at the end of a line before a hyphenation break.
style.properties.hyphenate-character.val:
The user-agent selects an appropriate string based on the content language's typographic conventions.
      This is the default property value, and only needs to be explicitly set in order to override a different inherited value.
style.properties.hyphenate-limit-chars.d: The hyphenate-limit-chars CSS property specifies the minimum word length to allow hyphenation of words as well as the minimum number of characters before and after the hyphen.
style.properties.hyphenate-limit-chars.v: The first value is the minimum word length before words should be hyphenated. The second value is the minimum number of characters before the hyphen. The third value is the minimum number of characters after the hyphen.

The first value is the minimum word length before words should be hyphenated. The second value is the minimum number of characters before the hyphen. The minimum number of characters after the hyphen will be set equal to the second value.
The value is the minimum word length before words should be hyphenated. The minimum number of characters before and after the hyphen will be set to auto.
style.properties.hyphens.description: The hyphens CSS property specifies how words should be hyphenated when text wraps across multiple lines. It can prevent hyphenation entirely, hyphenate at manually-specified points within the text, or let the browser automatically insert hyphens where appropriate.
style.properties.hyphens.values.auto.des: The browser is free to automatically break words at appropriate hyphenation points, following whatever rules it chooses. However, suggested line break opportunities (see Suggesting line break opportunities below) will override automatic break point selection when present.
style.properties.hyphens.values.manual.d: Default value. Words are broken for line-wrapping only where characters inside the word suggest line break opportunities. See Suggesting line break opportunities below for details.
style.properties.hyphens.values.none.des: Words are not broken at line breaks, even if characters inside the words suggest line break points. Lines will only wrap at whitespace.
style.properties.image-orientation.descr: The image-orientation CSS property specifies a layout-independent correction to the orientation of an image.
style.properties.image-orientation.value: After rotating by the precededing angle, the image is flipped horizontally. Defaults to 0deg if the angle is ommitted.
Default initial value. The EXIF information contained in the image is used to rotate the image appropriately.
Does not apply any additional image rotation; the image is oriented as encoded or as other CSS property values dictate.
style.properties.image-rendering.descrip: The image-rendering CSS property sets an image scaling algorithm. The property applies to an element itself, to any images set in its other properties, and to its descendants.
The scaling algorithm is UA dependent. Since version 1.9 (Firefox 3.0), Gecko uses bilinear resampling (high quality).
The image is scaled with an algorithm that preserves contrast and edges in the image. Generally intended for images such as pixel art or line drawings, no blurring or color smoothing occurs.

Identical to smooth, but with a preference for higher-quality scaling. If system resources are constrained, images with high-quality should be prioritized over those with any other value, when considering which images to degrade the quality of and to what degree.
The image is scaled with the "nearest neighbor" or similar algorithm, preserving a "pixelated" look as the image changes in size.

The image should be scaled with an algorithm that maximizes the appearance of the image. In particular, scaling algorithms that "smooth" colors are acceptable, such as bilinear interpolation. This is intended for images such as photos.
style.properties.image-resolution.descri: The image-resolution CSS property specifies the intrinsic resolution of all raster images used in or on the element. It affects content images such as replaced elements and generated content, and decorative images such as background-image images.
style.properties.image-resolution.values: Uses the intrinsic resolution as specified by the image format. If the image does not specify its own resolution, the explicitly specified resolution is used (if given), else it defaults to 1dppx (1 image pixel per CSS px unit).

If the snap keyword is provided, the computed resolution is the specified resolution rounded to the nearest value that would map one image pixel to an integer number of device pixels. If the resolution is taken from the image, then the used intrinsic resolution is the image's native resolution similarly adjusted.
style.properties.ime-mode.description: Controls the state of the input method editor for text fields.
The input method editor is initially active; text entry is performed using it unless the user specifically dismisses it.
style.properties.ime-mode.values.auto.de: No change is made to the current input method editor state. This is the default.
style.properties.ime-mode.values.disable: The input method editor is disabled and may not be activated by the user.
style.properties.ime-mode.values.inactiv: The input method editor is initially inactive, but the user may activate it if they wish.
The IME state should be normal; this value can be used in a user style sheet to override the page setting.
style.properties.inherits.description: Specifies the inherit flag of the custom property registration represented by the @property rule, controlling whether or not the property inherits by default.
style.properties.initial-letter-align.de: The initial-letter-align CSS property specifies the alignment of initial letters within a paragraph.
style.properties.initial-letter-align.va: As described above, the cap height of the initial letter aligns with the cap height of the first line of text. The baseline of the initial letter aligns with the baseline of the Nth text baseline.
The user agent selects the value which corresponds to the language of the text. Western languages would default to alphabetic, CJK languages to ideographic, and some Indic languages to hanging.
The hanging baseline of the initial letter aligns with the hanging baseline of the first line of text.
The initial letter is centered in the N-line area.
style.properties.initial-letter.descript: The initial-letter CSS property sets styling for dropped, raised, and sunken initial letters.
style.properties.initial-letter.values.n: No special initial-letter effect. Text behaves as normal.
style.properties.initial-value.descripti: Specifies the initial value of the custom property registration represented by the @property rule, controlling the property’s initial value.
style.properties.inline-size.description: The inline-size CSS property defines the horizontal or vertical size of an element's block, depending on its writing mode. It corresponds to either the width or the height property, depending on the value of writing-mode.
style.properties.inline-size.values.auto: Depends on the values of other properties.
style.properties.input-security.descript: Enables or disables the obscuring a sensitive test input.
style.properties.inset-block-end.descrip: The inset-block-end CSS property defines the logical block end offset of an element, which maps to a physical inset depending on the element's writing mode, directionality, and text orientation. It corresponds to the top, right, bottom, or left property depending on the values defined for writing-mode, direction, and text-orientation.
style.properties.inset-block-start.descr: The inset-block-start CSS property defines the logical block start offset of an element, which maps to a physical inset depending on the element's writing mode, directionality, and text orientation. It corresponds to the top, right, bottom, or left property depending on the values defined for writing-mode, direction, and text-orientation.
style.properties.inset-block.description: The inset-block CSS property defines the logical block start and end offsets of an element, which maps to physical offsets depending on the element's writing mode, directionality, and text orientation. It corresponds to the top and bottom, or right and left properties depending on the values defined for writing-mode, direction, and text-orientation.
style.properties.inset-inline-end.descri: The inset-inline-end CSS property defines the logical inline end inset of an element, which maps to a physical offset depending on the element's writing mode, directionality, and text orientation. It corresponds to the top, right, bottom, or left property depending on the values defined for writing-mode, direction, and text-orientation.
style.properties.inset-inline-start.desc: The inset-inline-start CSS property defines the logical inline start inset of an element, which maps to a physical offset depending on the element's writing mode, directionality, and text orientation. It corresponds to the top, right, bottom, or left property depending on the values defined for writing-mode, direction, and text-orientation.
style.properties.inset-inline.descriptio: The inset-inline CSS property defines the logical start and end offsets of an element in the inline direction, which maps to physical offsets depending on the element's writing mode, directionality, and text orientation. It corresponds to the top and bottom, or right and left properties depending on the values defined for writing-mode, direction, and text-orientation.
style.properties.inset.description: The inset CSS property is a shorthand that corresponds to the top, right, bottom, and/or left properties. It has the same multi-value syntax of the margin shorthand.
style.properties.isolation.description: The isolation CSS property determines whether an element must create a new stacking context.
style.properties.isolation.values.auto.d: A new stacking context is created only if one of the properties applied to the element requires it.
style.properties.isolation.values.isolat: A new stacking context must be created.
style.properties.justify-content.descrip: The CSS justify-content property defines how the browser distributes space between and around content items along the main-axis of a flex container, and the inline axis of a grid container.
The items are packed flush to each other toward the center of the alignment container along the main axis.
The items are packed flush to each other toward the end edge of the alignment container in the main axis.

The items are packed flush to each other toward the edge of the alignment container depending on the flex container's main-end side.
      This only applies to flex layout items. For items that are not children of a flex container, this value is treated like end.

The items are packed flush to each other toward the edge of the alignment container depending on the flex container's main-start side.
      This only applies to flex layout items. For items that are not children of a flex container, this value is treated like start.

The items are packed flush with each other toward the left edge of the alignment container. When the property's horizontal axis is not parallel with the inline axis, such as when flex-direction: column; is set, this value behaves like start.

Behaves as stretch, except in the case of multi-column containers with a non-auto column-width, in which case the columns take their specified column-width rather than stretching to fill the container. As stretch behaves as start in flex containers, normal also behaves as start.

The items are packed flush to each other toward the right edge of the alignment container in the appropriate axis. If the property's axis is not parallel with the inline axis (in a grid container) or the main-axis (in a flexbox container), this value behaves like start.
If the item overflows the alignment container, then the item is aligned as if the alignment mode is start. The desired alignment will not be implemented.

The items are evenly distributed within the alignment container along the main axis. The spacing between each pair of adjacent items is the same. The empty space before the first and after the last item equals half of the space between each pair of adjacent items.

The items are evenly distributed within the alignment container along the main axis. The spacing between each pair of adjacent items is the same. The first item is flush with the main-start edge, and the last item is flush with the main-end edge.

The items are evenly distributed within the alignment container along the main axis. The spacing between each pair of adjacent items, the main-start edge and the first item, and the main-end edge and the last item, are all exactly the same.
The items are packed flush to each other toward the start edge of the alignment container in the main axis.

If the combined size of the items along the main axis is less than the size of the alignment container, any auto-sized items have their size increased equally (not proportionally), while still respecting the constraints imposed by max-height/max-width (or equivalent functionality), so that the combined size exactly fills the alignment container along the main axis.
    
      Note: While stretch is supported by flexible boxes (flexbox), when applied on a flexbox, as stretching is controlled by flex, stretch behaves as start.
Even if the item overflows the alignment container, the desired alignment will be implemented. Unlike safe, which will ignore the desired alignment in favor of preventing overflow.
style.properties.justify-items.descripti: The CSS justify-items property defines the default justify-self for all items of the box, giving them all a default way of justifying each box along the appropriate axis.
style.properties.justify-items.values.ba:
Specifies participation in first- or last-baseline alignment: aligns the alignment baseline of the box’s first or last baseline set with the corresponding baseline in the shared first or last baseline set of all the boxes in its baseline-sharing group.
      The fallback alignment for first baseline is start, the one for last baseline is end.

Specifies participation in first- or last-baseline alignment: aligns the alignment baseline of the box's first or last baseline set with the corresponding baseline in the shared first or last baseline set of all the boxes in its baseline-sharing group.
      The fallback alignment for first baseline is start, the one for last baseline is end.
style.properties.justify-items.values.ce: The items are packed flush to each other toward the center of the alignment container.
style.properties.justify-items.values.en: The item is packed flush to each other toward the end edge of the alignment container in the appropriate axis.
style.properties.justify-items.values.fi:
Specifies participation in first- or last-baseline alignment: aligns the alignment baseline of the box's first or last baseline set with the corresponding baseline in the shared first or last baseline set of all the boxes in its baseline-sharing group.
      The fallback alignment for first baseline is start, the one for last baseline is end.
style.properties.justify-items.values.fl: For items that are not children of a flex container, this value is treated like end.
For items that are not children of a flex container, this value is treated like start.
style.properties.justify-items.values.la:
Specifies participation in first- or last-baseline alignment: aligns the alignment baseline of the box's first or last baseline set with the corresponding baseline in the shared first or last baseline set of all the boxes in its baseline-sharing group.
      The fallback alignment for first baseline is start, the one for last baseline is end.
style.properties.justify-items.values.le: The items are packed flush to each other toward the left edge of the alignment container. If the property's axis is not parallel with the inline axis, this value behaves like start.

Makes the value inherited by the box descendants. Note that if a descendant has a justify-self: auto value, the legacy keyword is not considered by the descend, only the left, right, or center value associated to it.
style.properties.justify-items.values.no:
The effect of this keyword is dependent of the layout mode we are in:
    
      In block-level layouts, the keyword is a synonym of start.
      In absolutely-positioned layouts, the keyword behaved like start on replaced absolutely-positioned boxes, and as stretch on all other absolutely-positioned boxes.
      In table cell layouts, this keyword has no meaning as this property is ignored.
      In flexbox layouts, this keyword has no meaning as this property is ignored.
      In grid layouts, this keyword leads to a behavior similar to the one of stretch, except for boxes with an aspect ratio or an intrinsic sizes where it behaves like start.
style.properties.justify-items.values.ri: The items are packed flush to each other toward the right edge of the alignment container in the appropriate axis. If the property's axis is not parallel with the inline axis, this value behaves like start.
style.properties.justify-items.values.sa: If the size of the item overflows the alignment container, the item is instead aligned as if the alignment mode were start.
style.properties.justify-items.values.se: The item is packed flush to the edge of the alignment container of the end side of the item, in the appropriate axis.
The item is packed flush to the edge of the alignment container of the start side of the item, in the appropriate axis.
style.properties.justify-items.values.st: The item is packed flush to each other toward the start edge of the alignment container in the appropriate axis.

If the combined size of the items is less than the size of the alignment container, any auto-sized items have their size increased equally (not proportionally), while still respecting the constraints imposed by max-height/max-width (or equivalent functionality), so that the combined size exactly fills the alignment container.
style.properties.justify-items.values.un: Regardless of the relative sizes of the item and alignment container, the given alignment value is honored.
style.properties.justify-self.descriptio: The CSS justify-self property sets the way a box is justified inside its alignment container along the appropriate axis.
style.properties.justify-self.values.aut: The value used is the value of the justify-items property of the parents box, unless the box has no parent, or is absolutely positioned, in these cases, auto represents normal.
style.properties.justify-self.values.bas:
Specifies participation in first- or last-baseline alignment: aligns the alignment baseline of the box’s first or last baseline set with the corresponding baseline in the shared first or last baseline set of all the boxes in its baseline-sharing group.
      The fallback alignment for first baseline is start, the one for last baseline is end.

Specifies participation in first- or last-baseline alignment: aligns the alignment baseline of the box's first or last baseline set with the corresponding baseline in the shared first or last baseline set of all the boxes in its baseline-sharing group.
      The fallback alignment for first baseline is start, the one for last baseline is end.
style.properties.justify-self.values.cen: The items are packed flush to each other toward the center of the alignment container.
style.properties.justify-self.values.end: The item is packed flush to each other toward the end edge of the alignment container in the appropriate axis.
style.properties.justify-self.values.fir:
Specifies participation in first- or last-baseline alignment: aligns the alignment baseline of the box's first or last baseline set with the corresponding baseline in the shared first or last baseline set of all the boxes in its baseline-sharing group.
      The fallback alignment for first baseline is start, the one for last baseline is end.
style.properties.justify-self.values.fle: For items that are not children of a flex container, this value is treated like end.
For items that are not children of a flex container, this value is treated like start.
style.properties.justify-self.values.las:
Specifies participation in first- or last-baseline alignment: aligns the alignment baseline of the box's first or last baseline set with the corresponding baseline in the shared first or last baseline set of all the boxes in its baseline-sharing group.
      The fallback alignment for first baseline is start, the one for last baseline is end.
style.properties.justify-self.values.lef: The items are packed flush to each other toward the left edge of the alignment container. If the property's axis is not parallel with the inline axis, this value behaves like start.
style.properties.justify-self.values.nor:
The effect of this keyword is dependent of the layout mode we are in:
    
      In block-level layouts, the keyword is a synonym of start.
      In absolutely-positioned layouts, the keyword behaves like start on replaced absolutely-positioned boxes, and as stretch on all other absolutely-positioned boxes.
      In table cell layouts, this keyword has no meaning as this property is ignored.
      In flexbox layouts, this keyword has no meaning as this property is ignored.
      In grid layouts, this keyword leads to a behavior similar to the one of stretch, except for boxes with an aspect ratio or an intrinsic sizes where it behaves like start.
style.properties.justify-self.values.rig: The items are packed flush to each other toward the right edge of the alignment container in the appropriate axis. If the property's axis is not parallel with the inline axis, this value behaves like start.
style.properties.justify-self.values.saf: If the size of the item overflows the alignment container, the item is instead aligned as if the alignment mode were start.
style.properties.justify-self.values.sel: The item is packed flush to the edge of the alignment container of the end side of the item, in the appropriate axis.
The item is packed flush to the edge of the alignment container of the start side of the item, in the appropriate axis.
style.properties.justify-self.values.sta: The item is packed flush to each other toward the start edge of the alignment container in the appropriate axis.
style.properties.justify-self.values.str: If the combined size of the items is less than the size of the alignment container, any auto-sized items have their size increased equally (not proportionally), while still respecting the constraints imposed by max-height/max-width (or equivalent functionality), so that the combined size exactly fills the alignment container.
style.properties.justify-self.values.uns: Regardless of the relative sizes of the item and alignment container, the given alignment value is honored.
style.properties.justify-tracks.descript: The justify-tracks CSS property sets the alignment in the masonry axis for grid containers that have masonry in their inline axis.
style.properties.justify-tracks.values.c: The items are packed flush to each other toward the center of the alignment container along the masonry axis.
style.properties.justify-tracks.values.e: The items are packed flush to each other toward the end edge of the alignment container in the masonry axis.
style.properties.justify-tracks.values.l: The items are packed flush to each other toward the left edge of the alignment container.
style.properties.justify-tracks.values.r: The items are packed flush to each other toward the right edge of the alignment container.
style.properties.justify-tracks.values.s: The items are evenly distributed within the alignment container along the masonry axis. The spacing between each pair of adjacent items is the same. The empty space before the first and after the last item equals half of the space between each pair of adjacent items.

The items are evenly distributed within the alignment container along the masonry axis. The spacing between each pair of adjacent items is the same. The first item is flush with the main-start edge, and the last item is flush with the main-end edge.

The items are evenly distributed within the alignment container along the masonry axis. The spacing between each pair of adjacent items, the main-start edge and the first item, and the main-end edge and the last item, are all exactly the same.
The items are packed flush to each other toward the start edge of the alignment container in the masonry axis.
The items stretch along the masonry axis to fill the content box. Items with definite size do not stretch.
style.properties.kerning.description: Indicates whether the user agent should adjust inter-glyph spacing based on kerning tables that are included in the relevant font or instead disable auto-kerning and set inter-character spacing to a specific length.
style.properties.kerning.values.auto.des: Indicates that the user agent should adjust inter-glyph spacing based on kerning tables that are included in the font that will be used.
style.properties.left.description: The left CSS property participates in specifying the horizontal position of a positioned element. It has no effect on non-positioned elements.
style.properties.left.values.auto.descri:
Specifies that:
    
      for absolutely positioned elements, the position of the element is based on the right property, while width: auto is treated as a width based on the content; or if right is also auto, the element is positioned where it should horizontally be positioned if it were a static element.
      for relatively positioned elements, the distance of the element from its normal position is based on the right property; or if right is also auto, the element is not moved horizontally at all.
style.properties.left.values.inherit.des: Specifies that the value is the same as the computed value from its parent element (which might not be its containing block). This computed value is then handled as if it were a <length>, <percentage>, or the auto keyword.
style.properties.letter-spacing.descript: The letter-spacing CSS property sets the horizontal spacing behavior between text characters. This value is added to the natural spacing between characters while rendering the text. Positive values of letter-spacing causes characters to spread farther apart, while negative values of letter-spacing bring characters closer together.
style.properties.letter-spacing.values.n: The normal letter spacing for the current font. Unlike a value of 0, this keyword allows the user agent to alter the space between characters in order to justify text.
style.properties.lighting-color.descript: Defines the color of the light source for filter primitives 'feDiffuseLighting' and 'feSpecularLighting'.
style.properties.line-break.description: The line-break CSS property sets how to break lines of Chinese, Japanese, or Korean (CJK) text when working with punctuation and symbols.
style.properties.line-break.values.anywh: There is a soft wrap opportunity around every typographic character unit, including around any punctuation character or preserved white spaces, or in the middle of words, disregarding any prohibition against line breaks, even those introduced by characters with the GL, WJ, or ZWJ character class or mandated by the word-break property. The different wrapping opportunities must not be prioritized. Hyphenation is not applied.
Break text using the default line break rule.
style.properties.line-break.values.loose: Break text using the least restrictive line break rule. Typically used for short lines, such as in newspapers.
style.properties.line-break.values.norma: Break text using the most common line break rule.
style.properties.line-break.values.stric: Break text using the most stringent line break rule.
style.properties.line-clamp.description: The line-clamp property allows limiting the contents of a block container to the specified number of lines; remaining content is fragmented away and neither rendered nor measured. Optionally, it also allows inserting content into the last line box to indicate the continuity of truncated/interrupted content.
style.properties.line-gap-override.descr: Describes the line-gap metric of a font.
style.properties.line-height-step.descri: The line-height-step CSS property sets the step unit for line box heights. When the property is set, line box heights are rounded up to the closest multiple of the unit.
style.properties.line-height.description: The line-height CSS property sets the height of a line box. It's commonly used to set the distance between lines of text. On block-level elements, it specifies the minimum height of line boxes within the element. On non-replaced inline elements, it specifies the height that is used to calculate line box height.
style.properties.line-height.values.norm: Depends on the user agent. Desktop browsers (including Firefox) use a default value of roughly 1.2, depending on the element's font-family.
style.properties.list-style-image.descri: The list-style-image CSS property sets an image to be used as the list item marker.
style.properties.list-style-image.values: Specifies that no image is used as the marker. If this value is set, the marker defined in list-style-type will be used instead.
style.properties.list-style-position.des: The list-style-position CSS property sets the position of the ::marker relative to a list item.
style.properties.list-style-position.val: The ::marker is the first element among the list item's contents.
The ::marker is outside the principal block box.
style.properties.list-style-type.descrip: Used to construct the default contents of a list item's marker
Decimal numbers, padded by initial zeros.
Iroha is the old japanese ordering of syllabs.
Japanese formal numbering to be used in legal or financial document. The kanjis are designed so that they can't be modified to look like another correct one
Iroha is the old japanese ordering of syllabs.
Defines an anonymous style of the list.
style.properties.list-style.description: The list-style CSS shorthand property allows you to set all the list style properties at once.
style.properties.list-style.values.insid: The marker box is outside the principal block box, as described in the section on the ::marker pseudo-element below.
style.properties.list-style.values.outsi: The ::marker pseudo-element is an inline element placed immediately before all ::before pseudo-elements in the principal block box, after which the element's content flows.
style.properties.list-style.values.symbo: Allows a counter style to be defined inline.
style.properties.margin-block-end.descri: The margin-block-end CSS property defines the logical block end margin of an element, which maps to a physical margin depending on the element's writing mode, directionality, and text orientation.
style.properties.margin-block-start.desc: The margin-block-start CSS property defines the logical block start margin of an element, which maps to a physical margin depending on the element's writing mode, directionality, and text orientation.
style.properties.margin-block.descriptio: The margin-block CSS shorthand property defines the logical block start and end margins of an element, which maps to physical margins depending on the element's writing mode, directionality, and text orientation.
style.properties.margin-bottom.descripti: The margin-bottom CSS property sets the margin area on the bottom of an element. A positive value places it farther from its neighbors, while a negative value places it closer.
style.properties.margin-bottom.values.au: The browser selects a suitable value to use. See margin.
style.properties.margin-inline-end.descr: The margin-inline-end CSS property defines the logical inline end margin of an element, which maps to a physical margin depending on the element's writing mode, directionality, and text orientation. In other words, it corresponds to the margin-top, margin-right, margin-bottom or margin-left property depending on the values defined for writing-mode, direction, and text-orientation.
style.properties.margin-inline-start.des: The margin-inline-start CSS property defines the logical inline start margin of an element, which maps to a physical margin depending on the element's writing mode, directionality, and text orientation. It corresponds to the margin-top, margin-right, margin-bottom, or margin-left property depending on the values defined for writing-mode, direction, and text-orientation.
style.properties.margin-inline.descripti: The margin-inline CSS shorthand property is a shorthand property that defines both the logical inline start and end margins of an element, which maps to physical margins depending on the element's writing mode, directionality, and text orientation.
style.properties.margin-left.description: The margin-left CSS property sets the margin area on the left side of an element. A positive value places it farther from its neighbors, while a negative value places it closer.
style.properties.margin-left.values.auto:
The left margin receives a share of the unused horizontal space, as determined mainly by the layout mode that is used. If the values of margin-left and margin-right are both auto, the calculated space is evenly distributed. This table summarizes the different cases:
    
      
        
          Value of display
          Value of float

            list-item, table-caption

            margin-right are set to auto. In this case, it
            is set to the value centering the element inside its parent.

            width, if fixed.

          flex, inline-flex
          any
          any
          
            0, except if there is any positive horizontal free space.
            In this case, it is evenly distributed to all horizontal
            auto margins.
          
          Flexbox layout mode
style.properties.margin-right.descriptio: The margin-right CSS property sets the margin area on the right side of an element. A positive value places it farther from its neighbors, while a negative value places it closer.
style.properties.margin-right.values.aut:
The right margin receives a share of the unused horizontal space, as determined mainly by the layout mode that is used. If the values of margin-left and margin-right are both auto, the calculated space is evenly distributed. This table summarizes the different cases:
    
      
        
          Value of display
          Value of float
          Value of position
          Computed value of auto
          Comment
        
      
      
        
          
            inline, inline-block,
            inline-table
          
          any
          static or relative
          0
          Inline layout mode
        
        
          
            block, inline, inline-block,
            block, table, inline-table,
            list-item, table-caption
          
          any
          static or relative
          
            0, except if both margin-left and
            margin-right are set to auto. In this case, it
            is set to the value centering the element inside its parent.
          
          Block layout mode
        
        
          
            block, inline, inline-block,
            block, table, inline-table,
            list-item, table-caption
          
          left or right
          static or relative
          0

            0, except if there is any positive horizontal free space.
            In this case, it is evenly distributed to all horizontal
            auto margins.
          
          Flexbox layout mode
style.properties.margin-top.description: The margin-top CSS property sets the margin area on the top of an element. A positive value places it farther from its neighbors, while a negative value places it closer.
The browser selects a suitable value to use. See margin.
style.properties.margin-trim.description: The margin-trim property allows the container to trim the margins of its children where they adjoin the container's edges.
style.properties.margin-trim.values.bloc: Margin of last block child with the container's edge is trimmed to zero.
Margin of the first block child with the container's edge is trimmed to zero.
Margins provided to the block children where they adjoin the container's edges are trimmed to zero without affecting the margins provided to the container.
style.properties.margin-trim.values.inli: Margin between the container's edge and the last inline child is trimmed to zero.
Margin between the container's edge and the first inline child is trimmed to zero.
Margins provided to the inline children where they adjoin the container's edges are trimmed to zero, without affecting the spacing at the beginning and end of the row.
style.properties.margin-trim.values.none: Margins are not trimmed by the container.
style.properties.margin.description: The margin CSS shorthand property sets the margin area on all four sides of an element.
style.properties.margin.values.auto.desc: The browser selects a suitable margin to use. For example, in certain cases this value can be used to center an element.
style.properties.marker-end.description: Specifies the marker that will be drawn at the last vertices of the given markable element.
Indicates that no marker symbol will be drawn at the given vertex or vertices.
style.properties.marker-end.values.url(): Indicates that the <marker> element referenced will be used.
style.properties.marker-mid.description: Specifies the marker that will be drawn at all vertices except the first and last.
Indicates that no marker symbol will be drawn at the given vertex or vertices.
style.properties.marker-mid.values.url(): Indicates that the <marker> element referenced will be used.
style.properties.marker-start.descriptio: Specifies the marker that will be drawn at the first vertices of the given markable element.
style.properties.marker-start.values.non: Indicates that no marker symbol will be drawn at the given vertex or vertices.
style.properties.marker-start.values.url: Indicates that the <marker> element referenced will be used.
style.properties.marker.description: Specifies the marker symbol that shall be used for all points on the sets the value for all vertices on the given 'path' element or basic shape.
style.properties.marker.values.none.desc: Indicates that no marker symbol will be drawn at the given vertex or vertices.
style.properties.marker.values.url().des: Indicates that the <marker> element referenced will be used.
style.properties.marks.description: The marks CSS at-rule descriptor, used with the @page at-rule, adds crop and/or cross marks to the presentation of the document. Crop marks indicate where the page should be cut. Cross marks are used to align sheets.
style.properties.mask-border-mode.descri: The mask-border-mode CSS property specifies the blending mode used in a mask border.
style.properties.mask-border-mode.values: The alpha values of the mask border image are used as the mask values.
The luminance values of the mask border image are used as the mask values.
style.properties.mask-border-outset.desc: The mask-border-outset CSS property specifies the distance by which an element's mask border is set out from its border box.
style.properties.mask-border-repeat.desc: The mask-border-repeat CSS property sets how the edge regions of a source image are adjusted to fit the dimensions of an element's mask border.
style.properties.mask-border-repeat.valu: The source image's edge regions are tiled (repeated) to fill the gap between each border. Tiles may be clipped to achieve the proper fit.
The source image's edge regions are tiled (repeated) to fill the gap between each border. Tiles may be stretched to achieve the proper fit.
The source image's edge regions are tiled (repeated) to fill the gap between each border. Extra space will be distributed in between tiles to achieve the proper fit.
The source image's edge regions are stretched to fill the gap between each border.
style.properties.mask-border-slice.descr: The mask-border-slice CSS property divides the image set by mask-border-source into regions. These regions are used to form the components of an element's mask border.
style.properties.mask-border-slice.value: Preserves the middle image region. Its width and height are sized to match the top and left image regions, respectively.
style.properties.mask-border-source.desc: The mask-border-source CSS property sets the source image used to create an element's mask border.
style.properties.mask-border-width.descr: The mask-border-width CSS property sets the width of an element's mask border.
style.properties.mask-border-width.value: The width of the mask border is made equal to the intrinsic width or height (whichever is applicable) of the corresponding mask-border-slice. If the image does not have the required intrinsic dimension, the corresponding border-width is used instead.
style.properties.mask-border.description: The mask-border CSS shorthand property lets you create a mask along the edge of an element's border.
style.properties.mask-clip.description: The mask-clip CSS property determines the area which is affected by a mask. The painted content of an element must be restricted to this area.
style.properties.mask-clip.values.border: The painted content is clipped to the border box.
This keyword behaves the same as border-box.
style.properties.mask-clip.values.conten: The painted content is clipped to the content box.
This keyword behaves the same as content-box.
style.properties.mask-clip.values.fill-b: The painted content is clipped to the object bounding box.
style.properties.mask-clip.values.no-cli: The painted content is not clipped.
style.properties.mask-clip.values.paddin: The painted content is clipped to the padding box.
This keyword behaves the same as padding-box.
style.properties.mask-clip.values.stroke: The painted content is clipped to the stroke bounding box.
style.properties.mask-clip.values.text.d: This keyword clips the mask image to the text of the element.
style.properties.mask-clip.values.view-b: Uses the nearest SVG viewport as reference box. If a viewBox attribute is specified for the element creating the SVG viewport, the reference box is positioned at the origin of the coordinate system established by the viewBox attribute and the dimension of the reference box is set to the width and height values of the viewBox attribute.
style.properties.mask-composite.descript: The mask-composite CSS property represents a compositing operation used on the current mask layer with the mask layers below it.
style.properties.mask-composite.values.a: The source is placed over the destination.
style.properties.mask-composite.values.e: The non-overlapping regions of source and destination are combined.
style.properties.mask-composite.values.i: The parts of source that overlap the destination, replace the destination.
style.properties.mask-composite.values.s: The source is placed, where it falls outside of the destination.
style.properties.mask-image.description:
The mask-image CSS property sets the image that is used as mask layer for an element.
  By default this means the alpha channel of the mask image will be multiplied with the alpha channel of the element. This can be controlled with the mask-mode property.
This keyword is interpreted as an opaque white image layer.
style.properties.mask-image.values.url(): Reference to a <mask element or to a CSS image.
style.properties.mask-mode.description: The mask-mode CSS property sets whether the mask reference defined by mask-image is treated as a luminance or alpha mask.
This keyword indicates that the transparency (alpha channel) values of the mask layer image should be used as the mask values.
style.properties.mask-mode.values.auto.d: Use alpha values if 'mask-image' is an image, luminance if a <mask> element or a CSS image.
style.properties.mask-mode.values.lumina: This keyword indicates that the luminance values of the mask layer image should be used as the mask values.
style.properties.mask-mode.values.match-:
If the mask-image property is of type <mask-source>, the luminance values of the mask layer image should be used as the mask values.
    If it is of type <image>, the alpha values of the mask layer image should be used as the mask values.
style.properties.mask-origin.description: The mask-origin CSS property sets the origin of a mask.
style.properties.mask-origin.values.bord: The position is relative to the border box.
style.properties.mask-origin.values.cont: The position is relative to the content box.
style.properties.mask-origin.values.fill: The position is relative to the object bounding box.
style.properties.mask-origin.values.padd: The position is relative to the padding box. For single boxes 0 0 is the upper left corner of the padding edge, 100% 100% is the lower right corner.
style.properties.mask-origin.values.stro: The position is relative to the stroke bounding box.
style.properties.mask-origin.values.view: Uses the nearest SVG viewport as reference box. If a viewBox attribute is specified for the element creating the SVG viewport, the reference box is positioned at the origin of the coordinate system established by the viewBox attribute and the dimension of the reference box is set to the width and height values of the viewBox attribute.
style.properties.mask-position.descripti: The mask-position CSS property sets the initial position, relative to the mask position layer set by mask-origin, for each defined mask image.
style.properties.mask-repeat.description: The mask-repeat CSS property sets how mask images are repeated. A mask image can be repeated along the horizontal axis, the vertical axis, both axes, or not repeated at all.
style.properties.mask-size.description: The mask-size CSS property specifies the sizes of the mask images. The size of the image can be fully or partially constrained in order to preserve its intrinsic ratio.
style.properties.mask-size.values.auto a: If the image has both intrinsic dimensions, it is rendered at that size. If it has no intrinsic dimensions and no intrinsic proportion, it is rendered at the size of the mask positioning area. If it has no dimensions but has a proportion, it's rendered as if contain had been specified instead. If the image has one intrinsic dimension and a proportion, it's rendered at the size determined by that one dimension and the proportion. If the image has one intrinsic dimension but no proportion, it's rendered using the intrinsic dimension and the corresponding dimension of the mask positioning area.
style.properties.mask-size.values.auto.d: If the image has an intrinsic proportion, then render it using the specified dimension and compute the other dimension from the specified dimension and the intrinsic proportion. If the image has no intrinsic proportion, use the specified dimension for that dimension. For the other dimension, use the image's corresponding intrinsic dimension if there is one. If there is no such intrinsic dimension, use the corresponding dimension of the mask positioning area.
style.properties.mask-size.values.contai: The image is rendered by preserving its intrinsic proportion at the largest size contained within or covering the mask positioning area. If the image has no intrinsic proportion, then it is rendered at the size of the mask positioning area.
