style.properties.scroll-padding-left.des: The scroll-padding-left property defines offsets for the left of the optimal viewing region of the scrollport: the region used as the target region for placing things in view of the user. This allows the author to exclude regions of the scrollport that are obscured by other content (such as fixed-positioned toolbars or sidebars) or to put more breathing room between a targeted element and the edges of the scrollport.
style.properties.scroll-padding-left.val: The offset is determined by the user agent. This will generally be 0px, but a user agent is able to detect and do something else if a non-zero value is more appropriate.
style.properties.scroll-padding-right.de: The scroll-padding-right property defines offsets for the right of the optimal viewing region of the scrollport: the region used as the target region for placing things in view of the user. This allows the author to exclude regions of the scrollport that are obscured by other content (such as fixed-positioned toolbars or sidebars) or to put more breathing room between a targeted element and the edges of the scrollport.
style.properties.scroll-padding-right.va: The offset is determined by the user agent. This will generally be 0px, but a user agent is able to detect and do something else if a non-zero value is more appropriate.
style.properties.scroll-padding-top.desc: The scroll-padding-top property defines offsets for the top of the optimal viewing region of the scrollport: the region used as the target region for placing things in view of the user. This allows the author to exclude regions of the scrollport that are obscured by other content (such as fixed-positioned toolbars or sidebars) or to put more breathing room between a targeted element and the edges of the scrollport.
style.properties.scroll-padding-top.valu: The offset is determined by the user agent. This will generally be 0px, but a user agent is able to detect and do something else if a non-zero value is more appropriate.
style.properties.scroll-padding.descript: The scroll-padding shorthand property sets scroll padding on all sides of an element at once, much like the padding property does for padding on an element.
style.properties.scroll-padding.values.a: The offset is determined by the user agent. This will generally be 0px, but the user agent is free to detect and do something else if a non-zero value is more appropriate.
style.properties.scroll-snap-align.descr: The scroll-snap-align property specifies the box's snap position as an alignment of its snap area (as the alignment subject) within its snap container's snapport (as the alignment container). The two values specify the snapping alignment in the block axis and inline axis, respectively. If only one value is specified, the second value defaults to the same value.
style.properties.scroll-snap-align.value: The center alignment of this box's scroll snap area, within the scroll container's snapport is a snap position in this axis.
The end alignment of this box's scroll snap area, within the scroll container's snapport is a snap position in this axis.
The box does not define a snap position in that axis.
The start alignment of this box's scroll snap area, within the scroll container's snapport is a snap position in this axis.
Defines the x and y coordinate within the element which will align with the nearest ancestor scroll container's snap-destination for the respective axis.
Specifies that this element does not contribute a snap point.
style.properties.scroll-snap-destination: Define the x and y coordinate within the scroll container's visual viewport which element snap points will align with.
style.properties.scroll-snap-points-x.de: Defines the positioning of snap points along the x axis of the scroll container it is applied to.
style.properties.scroll-snap-points-x.va: No snap points are defined by this scroll container.
Defines an interval at which snap points are defined, starting from the container's relevant start edge.
style.properties.scroll-snap-points-y.de: Defines the positioning of snap points along the y axis of the scroll container it is applied to.
style.properties.scroll-snap-points-y.va: No snap points are defined by this scroll container.
Defines an interval at which snap points are defined, starting from the container's relevant start edge.
style.properties.scroll-snap-stop.descri: The scroll-snap-stop CSS property defines whether or not the scroll container is allowed to "pass over" possible snap positions.
style.properties.scroll-snap-stop.values: The scroll container must not "pass over" a possible snap position; and must snap to the first of this elements' snap positions.
When the visual viewport of this element's scroll container is scrolled, it may "pass over" possible snap positions.
style.properties.scroll-snap-type-x.desc:
The scroll-snap-type-x CSS property defines how strictly snap points are enforced on the horizontal axis of the scroll container in case there is one.

Specifying any precise animations or physics used to enforce those snap points is not covered by this property but instead left up to the user agent.
style.properties.scroll-snap-type-y.desc:
The scroll-snap-type-y CSS property defines how strictly snap points are enforced on the vertical axis of the scroll container in case there is one.

Specifying any precise animations or physics used to enforce those snap points is not covered by this property but instead left up to the user agent.
style.properties.scroll-snap-type.descri: The scroll-snap-type CSS property sets how strictly snap points are enforced on the scroll container in case there is one.
style.properties.scroll-snap-type.values: The scroll container snaps to snap positions in its block axis only.
The scroll container snaps to snap positions in both of its axes independently (potentially snapping to different elements in each axis).
The scroll container snaps to snap positions in its inline axis only.
The visual viewport of this scroll container must snap to a snap position if it isn't currently scrolled.
When the visual viewport of this scroll container is scrolled, it must ignore snap points.

The visual viewport of this scroll container may snap to a snap position if it isn't currently scrolled. The user agent decides if it snaps or not based on scroll parameters. This is the default snap strictness if any snap axis is specified.
The scroll container snaps to snap positions in its horizontal axis only.
The scroll container snaps to snap positions in its vertical axis only.
style.properties.scroll-timeline-axis.de: The scroll-timeline-axis CSS property is used to specify the scrollbar direction that will be used to provide the timeline for a named scroll progress timeline animation, which is progressed through by scrolling a scrollable element (scroller) between top and bottom (or left and right). scroll-timeline is set on the scroller that will provide the timeline. See CSS scroll-driven animations for more details.
style.properties.scroll-timeline-axis.va: The scrollbar on the block axis of the scroller element, which is the axis in the direction perpendicular to the flow of text within a line. For horizontal writing modes, such as standard English, this is the same as y, while for vertical writing modes, it is the same as x. This is the default value.

The scrollbar on the inline axis of the scroller element, which is the axis in the direction parallel to the flow of text in a line. For horizontal writing modes, this is the same as x, while for vertical writing modes, this is the same as y.
The scrollbar on the horizontal axis of the scroller element.
The scrollbar on the vertical axis of the scroller element.
style.properties.scroll-timeline-name.de: The scroll-timeline-name CSS property is used to define the name of a named scroll progress timeline, which is progressed through by scrolling a scrollable element (scroller) between top and bottom (or left and right). scroll-timeline-name is set on the scroller that will provide the timeline.
style.properties.scroll-timeline.descrip: The scroll-timeline CSS shorthand property is used to define a named scroll progress timeline, which is progressed through by scrolling a scrollable element (scroller) between top and bottom (or left and right). scroll-timeline is set on the scroller that will provide the timeline. The starting scroll position represents 0% progress and the ending scroll position represents 100% progress. If the 0% position and 100% position coincide (i.e., the scroll container has no overflow to scroll), the timeline is inactive.
style.properties.scrollbar-3dlight-color: Determines the color of the top and left edges of the scroll box and scroll arrows of a scroll bar.
style.properties.scrollbar-arrow-color.d: Determines the color of the arrow elements of a scroll arrow.
style.properties.scrollbar-base-color.de: Determines the color of the main elements of a scroll bar, which include the scroll box, track, and scroll arrows.
style.properties.scrollbar-color.descrip: The scrollbar-color CSS property sets the color of the scrollbar track and thumb.
style.properties.scrollbar-darkshadow-co: Determines the color of the gutter of a scroll bar.
style.properties.scrollbar-face-color.de: Determines the color of the scroll box and scroll arrows of a scroll bar.
style.properties.scrollbar-gutter.descri: The scrollbar-gutter CSS property allows authors to reserve space for the scrollbar, preventing unwanted layout changes as the content grows while also avoiding unnecessary visuals when scrolling isn't needed.
style.properties.scrollbar-gutter.values: The initial value. Classic scrollbars create a gutter when overflow is scroll, or when overflow is auto and the box is overflowing. Overlay scrollbars do not consume space.
If a gutter would be present on one of the inline start/end edges of the box, another will be present on the opposite edge as well.
When using classic scrollbars, the gutter will be present if overflow is auto, scroll, or hidden even if the box is not overflowing. When using overlay scrollbars, the gutter will not be present.
style.properties.scrollbar-highlight-col: Determines the color of the top and left edges of the scroll box and scroll arrows of a scroll bar.
Determines the color of the bottom and right edges of the scroll box and scroll arrows of a scroll bar.
style.properties.scrollbar-track-color.d: Determines the color of the track element of a scroll bar.
style.properties.scrollbar-width.descrip: The scrollbar-width property allows the author to set the maximum thickness of an element's scrollbars when they are shown.
style.properties.shape-image-threshold.d: The shape-image-threshold CSS property sets the alpha channel threshold used to extract the shape using an image as the value for shape-outside.
style.properties.shape-margin.descriptio: The shape-margin CSS property sets a margin for a CSS shape created using shape-outside.
style.properties.shape-outside.descripti: The shape-outside CSS property defines a shape—which may be non-rectangular—around which adjacent inline content should wrap. By default, inline content wraps around its margin box; shape-outside provides a way to customize this wrapping, making it possible to wrap text around complex objects rather than simple boxes.
style.properties.shape-outside.values.bo: Defines the shape enclosed by the outside border edge. The shape follows the normal border radius shaping rules for the outside of the border.
style.properties.shape-outside.values.co: Defines the shape enclosed by the outside content edge. Each corner radius of this box is the larger of 0 or border-radius - border-width - padding.
style.properties.shape-outside.values.ma: Defines the shape enclosed by the outside margin edge. The corner radii of this shape are determined by the corresponding border-radius and margin values. If the border-radius / margin ratio is 1 or more, then the margin box corner radius is border-radius + margin. If the ratio is less than 1, then the margin box corner radius is border-radius + (margin * (1 + (ratio - 1) ^ 3)).
style.properties.shape-outside.values.no: The float area is unaffected. Inline content wraps around the element's margin box, like usual.
style.properties.shape-outside.values.pa: Defines the shape enclosed by the outside padding edge. The shape follows the normal border radius shaping rules for the inside of the border.
style.properties.shape-rendering.descrip: Provides hints about what tradeoffs to make as it renders vector graphics elements such as <path> elements and basic shapes such as circles and rectangles.
Emphasize the contrast between clean edges of artwork over rendering speed and geometric precision.
Emphasize geometric precision over speed and crisp edges.
Emphasize rendering speed over geometric precision and crisp edges.
style.properties.size-adjust.description: A multiplier for glyph outlines and metrics of a font.
style.properties.size.description: The size CSS at-rule descriptor, used with the @page at-rule, defines the size and orientation of the box which is used to represent a page. Most of the time, this size corresponds to the target size of the printed page if applicable.
style.properties.speak-as.description: The speak-as descriptor specifies how a counter symbol constructed with a given @counter-style will be represented in the spoken form. For example, an author can specify a counter symbol to be either spoken as its numerical value or just represented with an audio cue.
style.properties.src.description: @font-face descriptor. Specifies the resource containing font data. It is required, whether the font is downloadable or locally installed.
style.properties.src.values.format().des: Optional hint describing the format of the font resource.
style.properties.src.values.local().desc: Format-specific string that identifies a locally available copy of a given font.
style.properties.stop-color.description: Indicates what color to use at that gradient stop.
style.properties.stop-opacity.descriptio: Defines the opacity of a given gradient stop.
style.properties.stroke-dasharray.descri: Controls the pattern of dashes and gaps used to stroke paths.
style.properties.stroke-dasharray.values: Indicates that no dashing is used.
style.properties.stroke-dashoffset.descr: Specifies the distance into the dash pattern to start the dash.
style.properties.stroke-linecap.descript: Specifies the shape to be used at the end of open subpaths when they are stroked.
style.properties.stroke-linecap.values.b: Indicates that the stroke for each subpath does not extend beyond its two endpoints.
style.properties.stroke-linecap.values.r: Indicates that at each end of each subpath, the shape representing the stroke will be extended by a half circle with a radius equal to the stroke width.
style.properties.stroke-linecap.values.s: Indicates that at the end of each subpath, the shape representing the stroke will be extended by a rectangle with the same width as the stroke width and whose length is half of the stroke width.
style.properties.stroke-linejoin.descrip: Specifies the shape to be used at the corners of paths or basic shapes when they are stroked.
Indicates that a bevelled corner is to be used to join path segments.
Indicates that a sharp corner is to be used to join path segments.
Indicates that a round corner is to be used to join path segments.
style.properties.stroke-miterlimit.descr: When two line segments meet at a sharp angle and miter joins have been specified for 'stroke-linejoin', it is possible for the miter to extend far beyond the thickness of the line stroking the path.
style.properties.stroke-opacity.descript: Specifies the opacity of the painting operation used to stroke the current object.
style.properties.stroke-width.descriptio: Specifies the width of the stroke on the current object.
style.properties.stroke.description: Paints along the outline of the given graphical element.
style.properties.stroke.values.none.desc: No paint is applied in this layer.
style.properties.stroke.values.url().des: A URL reference to a paint server element, which is an element that defines a paint server: 'hatch', 'linearGradient', 'mesh', 'pattern', 'radialGradient' and 'solidcolor'.
style.properties.suffix.description: @counter-style descriptor. Specifies a <symbol> that is appended to the marker representation.
style.properties.symbols.description: @counter-style descriptor. Specifies the symbols used by the marker-construction algorithm specified by the system descriptor.
style.properties.syntax.description: Specifies the syntax of the custom property registration represented by the @property rule, controlling how the property’s value is parsed at computed value time.
style.properties.system.description: @counter-style descriptor. Specifies which algorithm will be used to construct the counter's representation based on the counter value.
Represents "sign-value" numbering systems, which, rather than using reusing digits in different positions to change their value, define additional digits with much larger values, so that the value of the number can be obtained by adding all the digits together.
style.properties.system.values.alphabeti: Interprets the list of counter symbols as digits to an alphabetic numbering system, similar to the default lower-alpha counter style, which wraps from "a", "b", "c", to "aa", "ab", "ac".
style.properties.system.values.cyclic.de: Cycles repeatedly through its provided symbols, looping back to the beginning when it reaches the end of the list.
style.properties.system.values.extends.d: Use the algorithm of another counter style, but alter other aspects.
style.properties.system.values.fixed.des: Runs through its list of counter symbols once, then falls back.
style.properties.system.values.numeric.d: interprets the list of counter symbols as digits to a "place-value" numbering system, similar to the default 'decimal' counter style.
Cycles repeatedly through its provided symbols, doubling, tripling, etc. the symbols on each successive pass through the list.
style.properties.tab-size.description: The tab-size CSS property is used to customize the width of tab characters (U+0009).
style.properties.table-layout.descriptio: The table-layout CSS property sets the algorithm used to lay out <table> cells, rows, and columns.
style.properties.table-layout.values.aut: The automatic table layout algorithm is used. The widths of the table and its cells are adjusted to fit the content. Most browsers use this algorithm by default.
style.properties.table-layout.values.fix:
The fixed table layout algorithm is used. When using this keyword, the table's width needs to be specified explicitly using the width property. If the value of the width property is set to autoor is not specified, the browser uses the automatic table layout algorithm, in which case the fixed value has no effect.The fixed table layout algorithm is faster than the automatic layout algorithm because the horizontal layout of the table depends only on the table's width, the width of the columns, and borders or cell spacing. The horizontal layout doesn't depend on the contents of the cells because it depends only on explicitly set widths.
    In the fixed table layout algorithm, the width of each column is determined as follows:
    
      A column element with explicit width sets the width for that column.
      Otherwise, a cell in the first row with explicit width determines the width for that column.
      Otherwise, the column gets the width from the shared remaining horizontal space.
    
    With this algorithm the entire table can be rendered once the first table row has been downloaded and analyzed. This can speed up rendering time over the "automatic" layout method, but subsequent cell content might not fit in the column widths provided. Cells use the overflow property to determine whether to clip any overflowing content, but only if the table has a known width; otherwise, they won't overflow the cells.
style.properties.text-align-last.descrip: The text-align-last CSS property sets how the last line of a block or a line, right before a forced line break, is aligned.
The affected line is aligned per the value of text-align, unless text-align is justify, in which case the effect is the same as setting text-align-last to start.
The inline contents are centered within the line box.
The same as right if direction is left-to-right and left if direction is right-to-left.
The text is justified. Text should line up their left and right edges to the left and right content edges of the paragraph.
The inline contents are aligned to the left edge of the line box.
The inline contents are aligned to the right edge of the line box.
The same as left if direction is left-to-right and right if direction is right-to-left.
style.properties.text-align.description: The text-align CSS property sets the horizontal alignment of the inline-level content inside a block element or table-cell box. This means it works like vertical-align but in the horizontal direction.
style.properties.text-align.values.cente: The inline contents are centered within the line box.
style.properties.text-align.values.end.d: The same as right if direction is left-to-right and left if direction is right-to-left.
style.properties.text-align.values.justi: Same as justify, but also forces the last line to be justified.
The inline contents are justified. Text should be spaced to line up its left and right edges to the left and right edges of the line box, except for the last line.
The inline contents are aligned to the left edge of the line box.
style.properties.text-align.values.match: Similar to inherit, but the values start and end are calculated according to the parent's direction and are replaced by the appropriate left or right value.
style.properties.text-align.values.right: The inline contents are aligned to the right edge of the line box.
style.properties.text-align.values.start: The same as left if direction is left-to-right and right if direction is right-to-left.
style.properties.text-anchor.description: Used to align (start-, middle- or end-alignment) a string of text relative to a given point.
The rendered characters are aligned such that the end of the resulting rendered text is at the initial current text position.
style.properties.text-anchor.values.midd: The rendered characters are aligned such that the geometric middle of the resulting rendered text is at the initial current text position.
style.properties.text-anchor.values.star: The rendered characters are aligned such that the start of the resulting rendered text is at the initial current text position.
style.properties.text-combine-upright.de: The text-combine-upright CSS property sets the combination of characters into the space of a single character. If the combined text is wider than 1em, the user agent must fit the contents within 1em. The resulting composition is treated as a single upright glyph for layout and decoration. This property only has an effect in vertical writing modes.
style.properties.text-combine-upright.va: Attempts to typeset all consecutive characters within the box horizontally, such that they take up the space of a single character within the vertical line of the box.

Attempts to display a sequence of consecutive ASCII digits (U+0030–U+0039) that has as many or fewer characters than the specified integer, such that it takes up the space of a single character within the vertical line box. If the integer is omitted, it computes to 2. Integers outside the range of 2-4 are invalid.
style.properties.text-decoration-color.d: The text-decoration-color CSS property sets the color of decorations added to text by text-decoration-line.
style.properties.text-decoration-line.de: The text-decoration-line CSS property sets the kind of decoration that is used on text in an element, such as an underline or overline.
style.properties.text-decoration-line.va: 文本闪烁（文本交替处于显示与隐藏状态）。客户代理都一致没有实现文本闪烁效果。考虑到为了支持使用 CSS 动画，该值也不宜使用。
The text blinks (alternates between visible and invisible). Conforming user agents may not blink the text. This value is deprecated in favor of CSS animations.
Each line of text has a decorative line going through its middle.
Each line of text has a decorative line above it.
Each line of text has a decorative line beneath it.
style.properties.text-decoration-skip-in: The text-decoration-skip-ink CSS property specifies how overlines and underlines are drawn when they pass over glyph ascenders and descenders.

The browser must interrupt underlines and overlines so that they do not touch or closely approach a glyph. This can be helpful with certain Chinese, Japanese, or Korean (CJK) fonts, where the auto behavior might not create interruptions.
The default — the browser may interrupt underlines and overlines so that they do not touch or closely approach a glyph. That is, they are interrupted where they would otherwise cross over a glyph.
Underlines and overlines are drawn across the full length of the text content, including parts that cross over glyph descenders and ascenders.
style.properties.text-decoration-skip.de: The text-decoration-skip CSS property sets what parts of an element's content any text decoration affecting the element must skip over. It controls all text decoration lines drawn by the element and also any text decoration lines drawn by its ancestors.
style.properties.text-decoration-skip.va: The text decoration is skipped over the box's margin, border, and padding areas. This only has an effect on decorations imposed by an ancestor; a decorating box never draws over its own box decoration.

The start and end of the text decoration is inset slightly (e.g., by half of the line thickness) from the content edge of the decorating box. Thus, adjacent elements receive separate underlines. (This is important in Chinese, where underlining is a form of punctuation.)
The same as spaces, except that only leading spaces are skipped.
Nothing is skipped. Thus, text decoration is drawn for all text content and across atomic inline-level boxes.
The entire margin box of the element is skipped if it is an atomic inline such as an image or inline-block.
All spacing is skipped: all Unicode white space characters and all word separators, plus any adjacent letter-spacing or word-spacing.
The same as spaces, except that only trailing spaces are skipped.
style.properties.text-decoration-style.d: The text-decoration-style CSS property sets the style of the lines specified by text-decoration-line. The style applies to all lines that are set with text-decoration-line.
style.properties.text-decoration-thickne: The text-decoration-thickness CSS property sets the stroke thickness of the decoration line that is used on text in an element, such as a line-through, underline, or overline.
The browser chooses an appropriate width for the text decoration line.

If the font file includes information about a preferred thickness, use that value. If the font file doesn't include this information, behave as if auto was set, with the browser choosing an appropriate thickness.
style.properties.text-decoration.descrip: The text-decoration shorthand CSS property sets the appearance of decorative lines on text. It is a shorthand for text-decoration-line, text-decoration-color, text-decoration-style, and the newer text-decoration-thickness property.
Each line of text has a line through the middle.
Each line of text has a line above it.
Sets the color of the decoration.
Sets the kind of decoration used, such as underline or line-through.
Sets the style of the line used for the decoration, such as solid, wavy, or dashed.
Sets the thickness of the line used for the decoration.
Each line of text is underlined.
style.properties.text-emphasis-color.des: The text-emphasis-color CSS property sets the color of emphasis marks. This value can also be set using the text-emphasis shorthand.
The text-emphasis-position CSS property sets where emphasis marks are drawn. Like ruby text, if there isn't enough room for emphasis marks, the line height is increased.
Draws marks to the left of the text in vertical writing mode.
Draws marks over the text in horizontal writing mode.
Draws marks to the right of the text in vertical writing mode.
Draws marks under the text in horizontal writing mode.
style.properties.text-emphasis-style.des: The text-emphasis-style CSS property sets the appearance of emphasis marks. It can also be set, and reset, using the text-emphasis shorthand.
style.properties.text-emphasis-style.val: Display large circles as marks. The filled circle is '●' (U+25CF), and the open circle is '○' (U+25CB).
Display small circles as marks. The filled dot is '•' (U+2022), and the open dot is '◦' (U+25E6).
Display double circles as marks. The filled double-circle is '◉' (U+25C9), and the open double-circle is '◎' (U+25CE).
The shape is filled with solid color. If neither filled nor open is present, this is the default.
Display sesames as marks. The filled sesame is '﹅' (U+FE45), and the open sesame is '﹆' (U+FE46).
Display triangles as marks. The filled triangle is '▲' (U+25B2), and the open triangle is '△' (U+25B3).
style.properties.text-emphasis.descripti: The text-emphasis CSS property applies emphasis marks to text (except spaces and control characters). It is a shorthand for text-emphasis-style and text-emphasis-color.
style.properties.text-emphasis.values.ci: Display large circles as marks. The filled circle is '●' (U+25CF), and the open circle is '○' (U+25CB). This is the default shape in horizontal writing modes when no other shape is given.
style.properties.text-emphasis.values.do: Display small circles as marks. The filled dot is '•' (U+2022), and the open dot is '◦' (U+25E6).
Display double circles as marks. The filled double-circle is '◉' (U+25C9), and the open double-circle is '◎' (U+25CE).
style.properties.text-emphasis.values.fi: The shape is filled with solid color. If neither filled nor open is present, this is the default.
style.properties.text-emphasis.values.se: Display sesames as marks. The filled sesame is '﹅' (U+FE45), and the open sesame is '﹆' (U+FE46). This is the default shape in vertical writing modes when no other shape is given.
style.properties.text-emphasis.values.tr: Display triangles as marks. The filled triangle is '▲' (U+25B2), and the open triangle is '△' (U+25B3).
style.properties.text-indent.description: The text-indent CSS property sets the length of empty space (indentation) that is put before lines of text in a block.
style.properties.text-indent.values.each: Indentation affects the first line of the block container as well as each line after a forced line break, but does not affect lines after a soft wrap break.
style.properties.text-indent.values.hang: Inverts which lines are indented. All lines except the first line will be indented.
style.properties.text-justify.descriptio: The text-justify CSS property sets what type of justification should be applied to text when text-align: justify; is set on an element.
style.properties.text-justify.values.aut: The browser chooses the best type of justification for the current situation based on a balance between performance and quality, but also on what is most appropriate for the language of the text (e.g., English, CJK languages, etc.). This is the default justification used if text-justify is not set at all.
style.properties.text-justify.values.dis: Exhibits the same behavior as inter-character; this value is kept for backwards compatibility.
style.properties.text-justify.values.int: The text is justified by adding space between characters (effectively varying letter-spacing), which is most appropriate for languages like Japanese.
Justification primarily changes spacing at word separators and at grapheme cluster boundaries in clustered scripts. This value is typically used for Southeast Asian scripts such as Thai.
Justification primarily changes spacing at word separators and at inter-graphemic boundaries in scripts that use no word spaces. This value is typically used for CJK languages.
The text is justified by adding space between words (effectively varying word-spacing), which is most appropriate for languages that separate words using spaces, like English or Korean.
style.properties.text-justify.values.kas: Justification primarily stretches Arabic and related scripts through the use of kashida or other calligraphic elongation.
style.properties.text-justify.values.non: The text justification is turned off. This has the same effect as not setting text-align at all, although it is useful if you need to turn justification on and off for some reason.
style.properties.text-orientation.descri: The text-orientation CSS property sets the orientation of the text characters in a line. It only affects text in vertical mode (when writing-mode is not horizontal-tb). It is useful for controlling the display of languages that use vertical script, and also for making vertical table headers.
style.properties.text-orientation.values: Rotates the characters of horizontal scripts 90° clockwise. Lays out the characters of vertical scripts naturally. Default value.
An alias to sideways that is kept for compatibility purposes.
Causes characters to be laid out as they would be horizontally, but with the whole line rotated 90° clockwise.

Lays out the characters of horizontal scripts naturally (upright), as well as the glyphs for vertical scripts. Note that this keyword causes all characters to be considered as left-to-right: the used value of direction is forced to be ltr.
On SVG elements, this keyword leads to use the value of the deprecated SVG properties glyph-orientation-vertical and glyph-orientation-horizontal.
style.properties.text-overflow.descripti: The text-overflow CSS property sets how hidden overflow content is signaled to users. It can be clipped, display an ellipsis ('…'), or display a custom string.
style.properties.text-overflow.values.cl: The default for this property. This keyword value will truncate the text at the limit of the content area, therefore the truncation can happen in the middle of a character. To clip at the transition between characters you can specify text-overflow as an empty string, if that is supported in your target browsers: text-overflow: '';.
style.properties.text-overflow.values.el: This keyword value will display an ellipsis ('…', U+2026 HORIZONTAL ELLIPSIS) to represent clipped text. The ellipsis is displayed inside the content area, decreasing the amount of text displayed. If there is not enough space to display the ellipsis, it is clipped.
style.properties.text-overflow.values.fa:
This function clips the overflowing inline content and applies a fade-out effect near the edge of the line box with complete transparency at the edge.
    The argument determines the distance over which the fade effect is applied. The <percentage> is resolved against the width of the line box. Values lower than 0 are clipped to 0. Values greater than the width of the line box are clipped to the width of the line box.
This keyword clips the overflowing inline content and applies a fade-out effect near the edge of the line box with complete transparency at the edge.
style.properties.text-rendering.descript: The text-rendering CSS property provides information to the rendering engine about what to optimize for when rendering text.
style.properties.text-rendering.values.a: The browser makes educated guesses about when to optimize for speed, legibility, and geometric precision while drawing text. For differences in how this value is interpreted by the browser, see the compatibility table.
style.properties.text-rendering.values.g:
The browser emphasizes geometric precision over rendering speed and legibility. Certain aspects of fonts — such as kerning — don't scale linearly. So this value can make text using those fonts look good.
    In SVG, when text is scaled up or down, browsers calculate the final size of the text (which is determined by the specified font size and the applied scale) and request a font of that computed size from the platform's font system. But if you request a font size of, say, 9 with a scale of 140%, the resulting font size of 12.6 doesn't explicitly exist in the font system, so the browser rounds the font size to 12 instead. This results in stair-step scaling of text.
    But the geometricPrecision property — when fully supported by the rendering engine — lets you scale your text fluidly. For large scale factors, you might see less-than-beautiful text rendering, but the size is what you would expect—neither rounded up nor down to the nearest font size supported by Windows or Linux.
    
      Note: WebKit precisely applies the specified value, but Gecko treats the value the same as optimizeLegibility.
style.properties.text-rendering.values.o: The browser emphasizes legibility over rendering speed and geometric precision. This enables kerning and optional ligatures.
The browser emphasizes rendering speed over legibility and geometric precision when drawing text. It disables kerning and ligatures.
style.properties.text-shadow.description: The text-shadow CSS property adds shadows to text. It accepts a comma-separated list of shadows to be applied to the text and any of its decorations. Each shadow is described by some combination of X and Y offsets from the element, blur radius, and color.
style.properties.text-size-adjust.descri: The text-size-adjust CSS property controls the text inflation algorithm used on some smartphones and tablets. Other browsers will ignore this property.
style.properties.text-size-adjust.values: Enables the browser's inflation algorithm. This value is used to cancel a none value previously set with CSS.
style.properties.text-transform.descript: The text-transform CSS property specifies how to capitalize an element's text. It can be used to make text appear in all-uppercase or all-lowercase, or with each word capitalized. It also can help improve legibility for ruby.
style.properties.text-transform.values.c: Puts the first typographic letter unit of each word in titlecase.
style.properties.text-transform.values.f: 通常用于 <ruby> 注释文本，该关键字将所有小假名字符转换为等效的全尺寸假名，以补偿在 ruby 中通常使用的小字体的可读性问题。
是一个关键字，它强制将字符（主要是表意文字和拉丁文字））--写在一个正方形内，使它们能够在通常的东亚文字（如中文或日文）中对齐。
style.properties.text-underline-offset.d: The text-underline-offset CSS property sets the offset distance of an underline text decoration line (applied using text-decoration) from its original position.
style.properties.text-underline-offset.v: The browser chooses the appropriate offset for underlines.
style.properties.text-underline-position: The text-underline-position CSS property specifies the position of the underline which is set using the text-decoration property's underline value.
The user agent uses its own algorithm to place the line at or under the alphabetic baseline.
The underline is aligned with the under edge of the element's content box.

If the font file includes information about a preferred position, use that value. If the font file doesn't include this information, behave as if auto was set, with the browser choosing an appropriate position.
In vertical writing-modes, this keyword forces the line to be placed on the left side of the text. In horizontal writing-modes, it is a synonym of under.
In vertical writing-modes, this keyword forces the line to be placed on the right side of the text. In horizontal writing-modes, it is a synonym of under.

Forces the line to be set below the alphabetic baseline, at a position where it won't cross any descenders. This is useful for ensuring legibility with chemical and mathematical formulas, which make a large use of subscripts.
style.properties.text-wrap.description: The text-wrap CSS property controls how text inside an element is wrapped. The different values provide:
style.properties.text-wrap.values.balanc: Text is wrapped in a way that best balances the number of characters on each line, enhancing layout quality and legibility. Because counting characters and balancing them across multiple lines is computationally expensive, this value is only supported for blocks of text spanning a limited number of lines (the Chromium implementation uses six wrapped lines or less), meaning that it is useful for cases such as headings or pull quotes.
style.properties.text-wrap.values.nowrap: Text does not wrap across lines. It will overflow its containing element rather than breaking onto a new line.
style.properties.text-wrap.values.wrap.d: Text is wrapped across lines at appropriate characters (for example spaces, in languages like English that use space separators) to minimize overflow. This is the default value.
style.properties.timeline-scope.descript: The timeline-scope CSS property modifies the scope of a named animation timeline.
style.properties.timeline-scope.values.n: There is no change in timeline scope.
style.properties.top.description: The top CSS property participates in specifying the vertical position of a positioned element. It has no effect on non-positioned elements.
style.properties.top.values.auto.descrip:
Specifies that:
    
      for absolutely positioned elements, the position of the element is based on the bottom property, while height: auto is treated as a height based on the content; or if bottom is also auto, the element is positioned where it should vertically be positioned if it were a static element.
      for relatively positioned elements, the distance of the element from its normal position is based on the bottom property; or if bottom is also auto, the element is not moved vertically at all.
style.properties.top.values.inherit.desc: Specifies that the value is the same as the computed value from its parent element (which might not be its containing block). This computed value is then handled as if it were a <length>, <percentage>, or the auto keyword.
style.properties.touch-action.descriptio: The touch-action CSS property sets how an element's region can be manipulated by a touchscreen user (for example, by zooming features built into the browser).
style.properties.touch-action.values.aut: Enable browser handling of all panning and zooming gestures.
style.properties.touch-action.values.man: Enable panning and pinch zoom gestures, but disable additional non-standard gestures such as double-tap to zoom. Disabling double-tap to zoom removes the need for browsers to delay the generation of click events when the user taps the screen. This is an alias for "pan-x pan-y pinch-zoom" (which, for compatibility, is itself still valid).
style.properties.touch-action.values.non: Disable browser handling of all panning and zooming gestures.
style.properties.touch-action.values.pan: Enable single-finger gestures that begin by scrolling in the given direction(s). Once scrolling has started, the direction may still be reversed. Note that scrolling "up" (pan-up) means that the user is dragging their finger downward on the screen surface, and likewise pan-left means the user is dragging their finger to the right. Multiple directions may be combined except when there is a simpler representation (for example, "pan-left pan-right" is invalid since "pan-x" is simpler, but "pan-left pan-down" is valid).

Enable single-finger gestures that begin by scrolling in the given direction(s). Once scrolling has started, the direction may still be reversed. Note that scrolling "up" (pan-up) means that the user is dragging their finger downward on the screen surface, and likewise pan-left means the user is dragging their finger to the right. Multiple directions may be combined except when there is a simpler representation (for example, "pan-left pan-right" is invalid since "pan-x" is simpler, but "pan-left pan-down" is valid).
启用以指定方向滚动开始的单指手势。一旦滚动开始，方向可能仍然相反。请注意，滚动“向上”（pan-up）意味着用户正在将其手指向下拖动到屏幕表面上，同样 pan-left 表示用户将其手指向右拖动。多个方向可以组合，除非有更简单的表示（例如，“pan-left pan-right”无效，因为“pan-x”更简单，而“pan-left pan-down”有效）。

Enable single-finger gestures that begin by scrolling in the given direction(s). Once scrolling has started, the direction may still be reversed. Note that scrolling "up" (pan-up) means that the user is dragging their finger downward on the screen surface, and likewise pan-left means the user is dragging their finger to the right. Multiple directions may be combined except when there is a simpler representation (for example, "pan-left pan-right" is invalid since "pan-x" is simpler, but "pan-left pan-down" is valid).

Enable single-finger gestures that begin by scrolling in the given direction(s). Once scrolling has started, the direction may still be reversed. Note that scrolling "up" (pan-up) means that the user is dragging their finger downward on the screen surface, and likewise pan-left means the user is dragging their finger to the right. Multiple directions may be combined except when there is a simpler representation (for example, "pan-left pan-right" is invalid since "pan-x" is simpler, but "pan-left pan-down" is valid).
Enable single-finger horizontal panning gestures. May be combined with pan-y, pan-up, pan-down and/or pinch-zoom.
Enable single-finger vertical panning gestures. May be combined with pan-x, pan-left, pan-right and/or pinch-zoom.
style.properties.touch-action.values.pin: Enable multi-finger panning and zooming of the page. This may be combined with any of the pan- values.
style.properties.transform-box.descripti: The transform-box CSS property defines the layout box to which the transform, individual transform properties translate,scale, and rotate, and transform-origin properties relate.
style.properties.transform-box.values.bo: The border box is used as the reference box. The reference box of a <table> is the border box of its table wrapper box, not its table box.
style.properties.transform-box.values.co: The content box is used as the reference box. The reference box of a <table> is the border box of its table wrapper box, not its table box.
style.properties.transform-box.values.fi: The object bounding box is used as the reference box. For elements with associated CSS layout box, acts as content-box.
style.properties.transform-box.values.st: The stroke bounding box is used as the reference box. For elements with associated CSS layout box, acts as border-box.
style.properties.transform-box.values.vi: The nearest SVG viewport is used as the reference box. If a viewBox attribute is specified for the SVG viewport creating element, the reference box is positioned at the origin of the coordinate system established by the viewBox attribute, and the dimension of the reference box is set to the width and height values of the viewBox attribute. For elements with associated CSS layout box, acts as border-box.
style.properties.transform-origin.descri: The transform-origin CSS property sets the origin for an element's transformations.
style.properties.transform-style.descrip: The transform-style CSS property sets whether children of an element are positioned in the 3D space or are flattened in the plane of the element.
Indicates that the children of the element are lying in the plane of the element itself.
Indicates that the children of the element should be positioned in the 3D-space.
style.properties.transform.description:
The transform CSS property lets you rotate, scale, skew, or translate an element.
  It modifies the coordinate space of the CSS visual formatting model.
style.properties.transform.values.matrix: Specifies a 2D transformation in the form of a transformation matrix of six values. matrix(a,b,c,d,e,f) is equivalent to applying the transformation matrix [a b c d e f]
Specifies a 3D transformation as a 4x4 homogeneous matrix of 16 values in column-major order.
style.properties.transform.values.none.d: Specifies that no transform should be applied.
style.properties.transform.values.rotate: Specifies a 2D rotation by the angle specified in the parameter about the origin of the element, as defined by the transform-origin property.
Specifies a clockwise 3D rotation by the angle specified in last parameter about the [x,y,z] direction vector described by the first 3 parameters.
Specifies a clockwise rotation by the given angle about the X axis.
Specifies a clockwise rotation by the given angle about the Y axis.
Specifies a clockwise rotation by the given angle about the Z axis.
style.properties.transform.values.scale(: Specifies a 2D scale operation by the [sx,sy] scaling vector described by the 2 parameters. If the second parameter is not provided, it is takes a value equal to the first.
style.properties.transform.values.scale3: Specifies a 3D scale operation by the [sx,sy,sz] scaling vector described by the 3 parameters.
style.properties.transform.values.scaleX: Specifies a scale operation using the [sx,1] scaling vector, where sx is given as the parameter.
style.properties.transform.values.scaleY: Specifies a scale operation using the [sy,1] scaling vector, where sy is given as the parameter.
style.properties.transform.values.scaleZ: Specifies a scale operation using the [1,1,sz] scaling vector, where sz is given as the parameter.
style.properties.transform.values.skew(): Specifies a skew transformation along the X and Y axes. The first angle parameter specifies the skew on the X axis. The second angle parameter specifies the skew on the Y axis. If the second parameter is not given then a value of 0 is used for the Y angle (ie: no skew on the Y axis).
style.properties.transform.values.skewX(: Specifies a skew transformation along the X axis by the given angle.
style.properties.transform.values.skewY(: Specifies a skew transformation along the Y axis by the given angle.
style.properties.transform.values.transl: Specifies a 2D translation by the vector [tx, ty], where tx is the first translation-value parameter and ty is the optional second translation-value parameter.
Specifies a 3D translation by the vector [tx,ty,tz], with tx, ty and tz being the first, second and third translation-value parameters respectively.
Specifies a translation by the given amount in the X direction.
Specifies a translation by the given amount in the Y direction.
Specifies a translation by the given amount in the Z direction. Note that percentage values are not allowed in the translateZ translation-value, and if present are evaluated as 0.
style.properties.transition-delay.descri: The transition-delay CSS property specifies the duration to wait before starting a property's transition effect when its value changes.
style.properties.transition-duration.des: The transition-duration CSS property sets the length of time a transition animation should take to complete. By default, the value is 0s, meaning that no animation will occur.
style.properties.transition-property.des: The transition-property CSS property sets the CSS properties to which a transition effect should be applied.
style.properties.transition-property.val: 属性名称。由小写字母 a 到 z，数字 0 到 9，下划线（_）和破折号（-）。第一个非破折号字符不能是数字。同时，不能以两个破折号开头。
All properties that can transition will.
style.properties.transition-timing-funct: The transition-timing-function CSS property sets how intermediate values are calculated for CSS properties being affected by a transition effect.
An author-defined cubic-Bezier curve, where the p1 and p3 values must be in the range of 0 to 1.
Equal to cubic-bezier(0.42, 0, 0.58, 1.0), starts transitioning slowly, speeds up, and then slows down again.
Equal to cubic-bezier(0.42, 0, 1.0, 1.0), starts off slowly, with the transition speed increasing until complete.
Equal to cubic-bezier(0, 0, 0.58, 1.0), starts transitioning quickly, slowing down as the transition continues.
Equal to cubic-bezier(0.25, 0.1, 0.25, 1.0), the default value, increases in velocity towards the middle of the transition, slowing back down at the end.
Includes pauses at both the 0% and 100% marks, effectively adding a step during the transition time.
Denotes a right-continuous function, so that the last jump happens when the animation ends;
There is no jump on either end. Instead, holding at both the 0% mark and the 100% mark, each for 1/n of the duration
Denotes a left-continuous function, so that the first jump happens when the transition begins;
Equal to cubic-bezier(0.0, 0.0, 1.0, 1.0), transitions at an even speed.

Displays the transition along n stops along the transition, displaying each stop for equal lengths of time. For example, if n is 5, there are 5 steps. Whether the transition holds temporarily at 0%, 20%, 40%, 60% and 80%, on the 20%, 40%, 60%, 80% and 100%, or makes 5 stops between the 0% and 100% along the transition, or makes 5 stops including the 0% and 100% marks (on the 0%, 25%, 50%, 75%, and 100%) depends on which of the following jump terms is used:
        
          jump-start
          
            Denotes a left-continuous function, so that the first jump happens when the transition begins;
          
          jump-end
          
            Denotes a right-continuous function, so that the last jump happens when the animation ends;
          
          jump-none
          
            There is no jump on either end. Instead, holding at both the 0% mark and the 100% mark, each for 1/n of the duration
          
          jump-both
          
            Includes pauses at both the 0% and 100% marks, effectively adding a step during the transition time.
          
          start
          
            Same as jump-start.
          
          end
          
            Same as jump-end.
style.properties.transition.description: The transition CSS property is a shorthand property for transition-property, transition-duration, transition-timing-function, and transition-delay.
style.properties.transition.values.all.d: Every property that is able to undergo a transition will do so.
style.properties.translate.description: The translate CSS property allows you to specify translation transforms individually and independently of the transform property. This maps better to typical user interface usage, and saves having to remember the exact order of transform functions to specify in the transform value.
style.properties.translate.values.none.d: Specifies that no translation should be applied.
style.properties.unicode-bidi.descriptio: The unicode-bidi CSS property, together with the direction property, determines how bidirectional text in a document is handled. For example, if a block of content contains both left-to-right and right-to-left text, the user-agent uses a complex Unicode algorithm to decide how to display the text. The unicode-bidi property overrides this algorithm and allows the developer to control the text embedding.
style.properties.unicode-bidi.values.bid: For inline elements this creates an override. For block container elements this creates an override for inline-level descendants not within another block container element. This means that inside the element, reordering is strictly in sequence according to the direction property; the implicit part of the bidirectional algorithm is ignored.
style.properties.unicode-bidi.values.emb: If the element is inline, this value opens an additional level of embedding with respect to the bidirectional algorithm. The direction of this embedding level is given by the direction property.
style.properties.unicode-bidi.values.iso: This keyword applies the isolation behavior of the isolate keyword to the surrounding content and the override behavior of the bidi-override keyword to the inner content.

This keyword indicates that the element's container directionality should be calculated without considering the content of this element. The element is therefore isolated from its siblings. When applying its bidirectional-resolution algorithm, its container element treats it as one or several U+FFFC Object Replacement Character, i.e. like an image.
style.properties.unicode-bidi.values.nor: The element does not offer an additional level of embedding with respect to the bidirectional algorithm. For inline elements, implicit reordering works across element boundaries.
style.properties.unicode-bidi.values.pla:
This keyword makes the elements directionality calculated without considering its parent bidirectional state or the value of the direction property. The directionality is calculated using the P2 and P3 rules of the Unicode Bidirectional Algorithm.
      This value allows the display of data that is already formatted using a tool following the Unicode Bidirectional Algorithm.
style.properties.unicode-range.descripti: @font-face descriptor. Defines the set of Unicode codepoints that may be supported by the font face for which it is declared.
style.properties.unicode-range.values.U+: Latin, Greek, Cyrillic, some punctuation and symbols.
Latin Extended-A. Accented characters for for Czech, Dutch, Polish, and Turkish.
Ethiopic Supplement. Extra Syllables for Sebatbeit, and Tonal marks
Latin Extended-B. Croatian, Slovenian, Romanian, Non-European and historic latin, Khoisan, Pinyin, Livonian, Sinology.
Latin Extended Additional. Vietnamese, German captial sharp s, Medievalist, Latin general use.
Greek Extended. Accented characters for polytonic Greek.
The Multilingual European Subset No. 1. Latin. Covers ~44 languages.
The Multilingual European Subset No. 2. Latin, Greek, and Cyrillic. Covers ~128 language.
The Multilingual European Subset No. 3. Covers all characters belonging to European scripts.
Ethiopic Extended. Extra Syllables for Me'en, Blin, and Sebatbeit.
CJK Radicals Supplement. Alternative forms of Kangxi Radicals.
CJK Unified Ideographs Extension A. Rare ideographs.
CJK (Chinese, Japanese, Korean) Unified Ideographs. Most common ideographs for modern Chinese and Japanese.
Cyrillic Supplement. Extra letters for Komi, Khanty, Chukchi, Mordvin, Kurdish, Aleut, Chuvash, Abkhaz, Azerbaijani, and Orok.
Arabic Supplement. Additional letters for African languages, Khowar, Torwali, Burushaski, and early Persian.
Latin-1 Supplement. Accented characters for Western European languages, common punctuation characters, multiplication and division signs.
Arabic Extended-A. Additional letters for African languages, European and Central Asian languages, Rohingya, Tamazight, Arwi, and Koranic annotation signs.
Japanese Kanji, Hiragana and Katakana characters plus Yen/Yuan symbol.
Ethiopic Extended-A. Extra characters for Gamo-Gofa-Dawro, Basketo, and Gumuz.
Alphabetic Presentation Forms. Ligatures for latin, Armenian, and Hebrew.
Arabic Presentation Forms-A. Contextual forms / ligatures for Persian, Urdu, Sindhi, Central Asian languages, etc, Arabic pedagogical symbols, word ligatures.
style.properties.user-modify.description: The user-modify property has no effect in Firefox. It was originally planned to determine whether or not the content of an element can be edited by a user.
style.properties.user-modify.values.read: Same as read-write, but rich text formatting will be lost.
The user is able to read and write contents.
style.properties.user-modify.values.writ: The user is able to edit the content, but not to read it.
style.properties.user-select.description: The user-select CSS property controls whether the user can select text. This doesn't have any effect on content loaded as part of a browser's user interface (its chrome), except in textboxes.
The content of the element shall be selected atomically: If a selection would contain part of the element, then the selection must contain the entire element including all its descendants. If a double-click or context-click occurred in sub-elements, the highest ancestor with this value will be selected.
style.properties.user-select.values.auto:
The used value of auto is determined as follows:
    
      On the ::before and ::after pseudo elements, the used value is none
      If the element is an editable element, the used value is contain
      Otherwise, if the used value of user-select on the parent of this element is all, the used value is all
      Otherwise, if the used value of user-select on the parent of this element is none, the used value is none
      Otherwise, the used value is text
style.properties.user-select.values.cont:
Enables selection to start within the element; however, the selection will be contained by the bounds of that element.
    
      Note: CSS UI 4 renamed the element value to contain.
style.properties.user-select.values.none: The text of the element and its sub-elements is not selectable. Note that the Selection object can contain these elements.
style.properties.user-select.values.text: The text can be selected by the user.
style.properties.user-zoom.description: The user-zoom CSS descriptor controls whether or not the user can change the zoom factor of a document defined by @viewport.
style.properties.vertical-align.descript: The vertical-align CSS property sets vertical alignment of an inline, inline-block or table-cell box.
style.properties.vertical-align.values.a: Align the dominant baseline of the parent box with the equivalent, or heuristically reconstructed, baseline of the element inline box.
style.properties.vertical-align.values.b: Align the 'alphabetic' baseline of the element with the 'alphabetic' baseline of the parent element.
Align the after edge of the extended inline box with the after-edge of the line box.
style.properties.vertical-align.values.m: Align the 'middle' baseline of the inline element with the middle baseline of the parent.
style.properties.vertical-align.values.s: Lower the baseline of the box to the proper position for subscripts of the parent's box. (This value has no effect on the font size of the element's text.)
Raise the baseline of the box to the proper position for superscripts of the parent's box. (This value has no effect on the font size of the element's text.)
style.properties.vertical-align.values.t: Align the bottom of the box with the after-edge of the parent element's font.
Align the top of the box with the before-edge of the parent element's font.
Align the before edge of the extended inline box with the before-edge of the line box.
style.properties.view-timeline-axis.desc: The view-timeline-axis CSS property is used to specify the scrollbar direction that will be used to provide the timeline for a named view progress timeline animation, which is progressed through based on the change in visibility of an element (known as the subject) inside a scrollable element (scroller). view-timeline-axis is set on the subject. See CSS scroll-driven animations for more details.
style.properties.view-timeline-axis.valu: The scrollbar on the block axis of the scroller element, which is the axis in the direction perpendicular to the flow of text within a line. For horizontal writing modes, such as standard English, this is the same as y, while for vertical writing modes, it is the same as x. This is the default value.

The scrollbar on the inline axis of the scroller element, which is the axis in the direction parallel to the flow of text in a line. For horizontal writing modes, this is the same as x, while for vertical writing modes, this is the same as y.
The scrollbar on the horizontal axis of the scroller element.
The scrollbar on the vertical axis of the scroller element.
style.properties.view-timeline-inset.des: The view-timeline-inset CSS property is used to specify one or two values representing an adjustment to the position of the scrollport (see Scroll container for more details) in which the subject element of a named view progress timeline animation is deemed to be visible. Put another way, this allows you to specify start and/or end inset (or outset) values that offset the position of the timeline.
style.properties.view-timeline-inset.val: If set, the corresponding scroll-padding (or equivalent longhand value) for that edge of the scrollport is used. If this is not set (or set to auto), the value will usually be 0, although some user agents may use heuristics to determine a different default value if appropriate.
style.properties.view-timeline-name.desc: The view-timeline-name CSS property is used to define the name of a named view progress timeline, which is progressed through based on the change in visibility of an element (known as the subject) inside a scrollable element (scroller). view-timeline is set on the subject.
style.properties.view-timeline.descripti: The view-timeline CSS shorthand property is used to define a named view progress timeline, which is progressed through based on the change in visibility of an element (known as the subject) inside a scrollable element (scroller). view-timeline is set on the subject.
style.properties.view-transition-name.de: The view-transition-name CSS property provides the selected element with a distinct identifying name (a <custom-ident>) and causes it to participate in a separate view transition from the root view transition — or no view transition if the none value is specified.
style.properties.view-transition-name.va: The selected element will not participate in a view transition.
style.properties.viewport-fit.descriptio: The border-block-style CSS property defines the style of the logical block borders of an element, which maps to a physical border style depending on the element's writing mode, directionality, and text orientation.
style.properties.visibility.description: The visibility CSS property shows or hides an element without changing the layout of a document. The property can also hide rows or columns in a <table>.
style.properties.visibility.values.colla:
The collapse keyword has different effects for different elements:
    
      For <table> rows, columns, column groups, and row groups, the row(s) or column(s) are hidden and the space they would have occupied is removed (as if display: none were applied to the column/row of the table). However, the size of other rows and columns is still calculated as though the cells in the collapsed row(s) or column(s) are present. This value allows for the fast removal of a row or column from a table without forcing the recalculation of widths and heights for the entire table.
      Collapsed flex items and ruby annotations are hidden, and the space they would have occupied is removed.
      For other elements, collapse is treated the same as hidden.
style.properties.visibility.values.hidde: The element box is invisible (not drawn), but still affects layout as normal. Descendants of the element will be visible if they have visibility set to visible. The element cannot receive focus (such as when navigating through tab indexes).
style.properties.white-space-collapse.de: The white-space-collapse CSS property controls how white space inside an element is collapsed.
style.properties.white-space-collapse.va:
The behavior is identical to preserve, except that:
    
      Any sequence of preserved white space always takes up space, including at the end of the line.
      A line-breaking opportunity exists after every preserved white space character, including between white space characters.
      Preserved spaces take up space and do not hang, thus affecting the box's intrinsic sizes (min-content size and max-content size).
White space sequences are collapsed, while segment break characters are preserved.
White space sequences are preserved, while tabs and segment break characters are converted to spaces.
White space sequences and segment break characters are preserved.
style.properties.white-space.description: The white-space CSS property sets how white space inside an element is handled.
style.properties.white-space.values.brea:
The behavior is identical to that of pre-wrap, except that:
    
      Any sequence of preserved white space always takes up space, including at the end of the line.
      A line-breaking opportunity exists after every preserved white space character, including between white space characters.
      Such preserved spaces take up space and do not hang, thus affecting the box's intrinsic sizes (min-content size and max-content size).
style.properties.white-space.values.norm: Sequences of white space are collapsed. Newline characters in the source are handled the same as other white space. Lines are broken as necessary to fill line boxes.
style.properties.white-space.values.nowr: Collapses white space as for normal, but suppresses line breaks (text wrapping) within the source.
style.properties.white-space.values.pre-:
Sequences of white space are collapsed. Lines are broken at newline characters, at
, and as necessary to fill line boxes.

Sequences of white space are preserved. Lines are broken at newline characters, at
, and as necessary to fill line boxes.
Sequences of white space are preserved. Lines are only broken at newline characters in the source and at
elements.
style.properties.widows.description: The widows CSS property sets the minimum number of lines in a block container that must be shown at the top of a page, region, or column.
style.properties.width.description: The width CSS property sets an element's width. By default, it sets the width of the content area, but if box-sizing is set to border-box, it sets the width of the border area.
style.properties.width.values.auto.descr: The browser will calculate and select a width for the specified element.
style.properties.width.values.fit-conten: Uses the fit-content formula with the available space replaced by the specified argument, i.e. min(max-content, max(min-content, <length-percentage>)).
Use the fit-content inline size or fit-content block size, as appropriate to the writing mode.
style.properties.will-change.description: The will-change CSS property hints to browsers how an element is expected to change. Browsers may set up optimizations before an element is actually changed. These kinds of optimizations can increase the responsiveness of a page by doing potentially expensive work before they are actually required.
style.properties.will-change.values.auto: This keyword expresses no particular intent; the user agent should apply whatever heuristics and optimizations it normally does.
style.properties.will-change.values.cont: Indicates that the author expects to animate or change something about the element's contents in the near future.
style.properties.will-change.values.scro: Indicates that the author expects to animate or change the scroll position of the element in the near future.
style.properties.word-break.description: The word-break CSS property sets whether line breaks appear wherever the text would otherwise overflow its content box.
style.properties.word-break.values.break: To prevent overflow, word breaks should be inserted between any two characters (excluding Chinese/Japanese/Korean text).
Has the same effect as overflow-wrap: anywhere combined with word-break: normal, regardless of the actual value of the overflow-wrap property.
style.properties.word-break.values.keep-: Word breaks should not be used for Chinese/Japanese/Korean (CJK) text. Non-CJK text behavior is the same as for normal.
style.properties.word-break.values.norma: Use the default line break rule.
style.properties.word-spacing.descriptio: The word-spacing CSS property sets the length of space between words and between tags.
style.properties.word-spacing.values.nor: The normal inter-word spacing, as defined by the current font and/or the browser.
style.properties.word-wrap.description: Specifies whether the UA may break within a word to prevent overflow when an otherwise-unbreakable string is too long to fit.
style.properties.word-wrap.values.break-: An otherwise unbreakable sequence of characters may be broken at an arbitrary point if there are no otherwise-acceptable break points in the line.
style.properties.word-wrap.values.normal: Lines may break only at allowed break points.
style.properties.writing-mode.descriptio: The writing-mode CSS property sets whether lines of text are laid out horizontally or vertically, as well as the direction in which blocks progress. When set for an entire document, it should be set on the root element (html element for HTML documents).
style.properties.writing-mode.values.hor: For ltr scripts, content flows horizontally from left to right. For rtl scripts, content flows horizontally from right to left. The next horizontal line is positioned below the previous line.
style.properties.writing-mode.values.lr-: Deprecated except for SVG1 documents. For CSS, use horizontal-tb instead.
Deprecated except for SVG1 documents. For CSS, use horizontal-tb instead.
Deprecated except for SVG1 documents. For CSS, use horizontal-tb instead.
style.properties.writing-mode.values.sid: For ltr scripts, content flows vertically from bottom to top. For rtl scripts, content flows vertically from top to bottom. All the glyphs, even those in vertical scripts, are set sideways toward the left.

For ltr scripts, content flows vertically from top to bottom. For rtl scripts, content flows vertically from bottom to top. All the glyphs, even those in vertical scripts, are set sideways toward the right.
style.properties.writing-mode.values.tb-: Deprecated except for SVG1 documents. For CSS, use vertical-lr instead.
Deprecated except for SVG1 documents. For CSS, use vertical-rl instead.
Deprecated except for SVG1 documents. For CSS, use vertical-lr instead.
style.properties.writing-mode.values.ver: For ltr scripts, content flows vertically from top to bottom, and the next vertical line is positioned to the right of the previous line. For rtl scripts, content flows vertically from bottom to top, and the next vertical line is positioned to the left of the previous line.

For ltr scripts, content flows vertically from top to bottom, and the next vertical line is positioned to the left of the previous line. For rtl scripts, content flows vertically from bottom to top, and the next vertical line is positioned to the right of the previous line.
style.properties.z-index.description: The z-index CSS property sets the z-order of a positioned element and its descendants or flex and grid items. Overlapping elements with a larger z-index cover those with a smaller one.
style.properties.z-index.values.auto.des: The box does not establish a new local stacking context. The stack level of the generated box in the current stacking context is 0.
style.properties.zoom.description: The non-standard zoom CSS property can be used to control the magnification level of an element. transform: scale() should be used instead of this property, if possible. However, unlike CSS Transforms, zoom affects the layout size of the element.
style.properties.zoom.values.normal.desc: Render this element at its normal size.
style.properties.zoom.values.reset.descr: Do not (de)magnify this element if the user applies non-pinch-based zooming (e.g. by pressing Ctrl - - or Ctrl + + keyboard shortcuts) to the document. Do not use this value, use the standard unset value instead.
style.pseudoClasses.:-moz-any().descript: Represents an element that is represented by the selector list passed as its argument. Standardized as :matches().
style.pseudoClasses.:-moz-any-link.descr: Represents an element that acts as the source anchor of a hyperlink. Applies to both visited and unvisited links.
style.pseudoClasses.:-moz-broken.descrip: The :-moz-broken CSS pseudo-class is a Mozilla extension that matches elements representing broken image links.
style.pseudoClasses.:-moz-drag-over.desc: The :-moz-drag-over CSS pseudo-class is a Mozilla extension that matches an element when a dragover event is called on it.
style.pseudoClasses.:-moz-first-node.des: The :-moz-first-node CSS pseudo-class is a Mozilla extension that represents any element that is the first child node of some other element. It differs from :first-child because it does not match a first-child element with (non-whitespace) text before it.
style.pseudoClasses.:-moz-focusring.desc: Non-standard. Matches an element that has focus and focus ring drawing is enabled in the browser.
style.pseudoClasses.:-moz-full-screen.de: Matches any element that has its fullscreen flag set. Standardized as :fullscreen.
style.pseudoClasses.:-moz-last-node.desc: The :-moz-last-node CSS pseudo-class is a Mozilla extension that represents any element that is the last child node of some other element. It differs from :last-child because it does not match a last-child element with (non-whitespace) text after it.
style.pseudoClasses.:-moz-loading.descri: The :-moz-loading CSS pseudo-class is a Mozilla extension that matches elements that can't be displayed because they have not started loading, such as images that haven't started to arrive yet. Note that images that are in the process of loading are not matched by this pseudo-class.
style.pseudoClasses.:-moz-only-whitespac: The :-moz-only-whitespace CSS pseudo-class matches elements that only contain text nodes that only contain whitespace. (This includes elements with empty text nodes and elements with no child nodes.)
style.pseudoClasses.:-moz-placeholder.de: Deprecated. Represents placeholder text in an input field. Use ::-moz-placeholder for Firefox 19+.
style.pseudoClasses.:-moz-submit-invalid: The :-moz-submit-invalid CSS pseudo-class is a Mozilla extension that represents any submit <button> on forms whose contents aren't valid based on their validation constraints.
style.pseudoClasses.:-moz-suppressed.des: The :-moz-suppressed CSS pseudo-class is a Mozilla extension that matches elements representing images that were suppressed because loading images from the specified site has been blocked.
style.pseudoClasses.:-moz-ui-invalid.des: Non-standard. Represents any validated form element whose value isn't valid
style.pseudoClasses.:-moz-ui-valid.descr: Non-standard. Represents any validated form element whose value is valid
The :-moz-user-disabled CSS pseudo-class is a Mozilla extension that matches elements representing images that were not loaded because images have been entirely disabled by the user's preferences.
style.pseudoClasses.:-moz-window-inactiv: The :-moz-window-inactive CSS pseudo-class is a Mozilla extension that matches any element while it's in an inactive window.
style.pseudoClasses.:-ms-fullscreen.desc: Matches any element that has its fullscreen flag set.
style.pseudoClasses.:-ms-input-placehold: Represents placeholder text in an input field. Note: for Edge use the pseudo-element ::-ms-input-placeholder. Standardized as ::placeholder.
style.pseudoClasses.:-ms-keyboard-active: Windows Store apps only. Applies one or more styles to an element when it has focus and the user presses the space bar.
style.pseudoClasses.:-ms-lang().descript: Represents an element that is in the language specified. Accepts a comma separated list of language tokens.
style.pseudoClasses.:-webkit-any().descr: Represents an element that is represented by the selector list passed as its argument. Standardized as :matches().
style.pseudoClasses.:-webkit-full-screen: Matches any element that has its fullscreen flag set. Standardized as :fullscreen.
style.pseudoClasses.:active.description: The :active CSS pseudo-class represents an element (such as a button) that is being activated by the user. When using a mouse, "activation" typically starts when the user presses down the primary mouse button.
style.pseudoClasses.:any-link.descriptio: The :any-link CSS pseudo-class selector represents an element that acts as the source anchor of a hyperlink, independent of whether it has been visited. In other words, it matches every <a> or <area> element that has an href attribute. Thus, it matches all elements that match :link or :visited.
style.pseudoClasses.:blank.description: The :blank CSS pseudo-class selects empty user input elements (e.g. <input> or <textarea>).
